RN   [24]
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=25378149; DOI=10.1523/JNEUROSCI.3369-14.2014;
RA   Gordon A., Adamsky K., Vainshtein A., Frechter S., Dupree J.L.,
RA   Rosenbluth J., Peles E.;
RT   "Caspr and caspr2 are required for both radial and longitudinal
RT   organization of myelinated axons.";
RL   J. Neurosci. 34:14820-14826(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-gated potassium channel that mediates
CC       transmembrane potassium transport in excitable membranes,
CC       primarily in the brain and the central nervous system, but also in
CC       the cardiovascular system. Prevents aberrant action potential
CC       firing and regulates neuronal output. Forms tetrameric potassium-
CC       selective channels through which potassium ions pass in accordance
CC       with their electrochemical gradient. The channel alternates
CC       between opened and closed conformations in response to the voltage
CC       difference across the membrane (PubMed:12527813, PubMed:21233214).
CC       Can form functional homotetrameric channels and heterotetrameric
CC       channels that contain variable proportions of KCNA1, KCNA2, KCNA4,
CC       KCNA5, KCNA6, KCNA7, and possibly other family members as well;
CC       channel properties depend on the type of alpha subunits that are
CC       part of the channel (PubMed:20696761). Channel properties are
CC       modulated by cytoplasmic beta subunits that regulate the
CC       subcellular location of the alpha subunits and promote rapid
CC       inactivation of delayed rectifier potassium channels (By
CC       similarity). In vivo, membranes probably contain a mixture of
CC       heteromeric potassium channel complexes, making it difficult to
CC       assign currents observed in intact tissues to any particular
CC       potassium channel family member. Homotetrameric KCNA2 forms a
CC       delayed-rectifier potassium channel that opens in response to
CC       membrane depolarization, followed by slow spontaneous channel
CC       closure (PubMed:23864368). In contrast, a heteromultimer formed by
CC       KCNA2 and KCNA4 shows rapid inactivation (PubMed:23864368).
CC       Contributes to the regulation of action potentials in neurons
CC       (PubMed:12527813, PubMed:17925011). KCNA2-containing channels play
CC       a presynaptic role and prevent hyperexcitability and aberrant
CC       action potential firing (PubMed:17634333, PubMed:17925011).
CC       Response to toxins that are selective for KCNA1, respectively for
CC       KCNA2, suggests that heteromeric potassium channels composed of
CC       both KCNA1 and KCNA2 play a role in pacemaking and regulate the
CC       output of deep cerebellar nuclear neurons (By similarity).
CC       Response to toxins that are selective for KCNA2-containing
CC       potassium channels suggests that in Purkinje cells, dendritic
CC       subthreshold KCNA2-containing potassium channels prevent random
CC       spontaneous calcium spikes, suppressing dendritic
CC       hyperexcitability without hindering the generation of somatic
CC       action potentials, and thereby play an important role in motor
CC       coordination (By similarity). KCNA2-containing channels play a
CC       role in GABAergic transmission from basket cells to Purkinje cells
CC       in the cerebellum, and thereby play an import role in motor
CC       coordination (PubMed:20696761). Plays a role in the induction of
CC       long-term potentiation of neuron excitability in the CA3 layer of
CC       the hippocampus (PubMed:23981714). May function as down-stream
CC       effector for G protein-coupled receptors and inhibit GABAergic
CC       inputs to basolateral amygdala neurons (By similarity). May
CC       contribute to the regulation of neurotransmitter release, such as
CC       gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) (By similarity). Contributes to the
CC       regulation of the axonal release of the neurotransmitter dopamine
CC       (PubMed:21233214). Reduced KCNA2 expression plays a role in the
CC       perception of neuropathic pain after peripheral nerve injury, but
CC       not acute pain (By similarity). Plays a role in the regulation of
CC       the time spent in non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep
CC       (PubMed:17925011). {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12527813,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17634333, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17925011,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20696761, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21233214,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23864368, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23981714,
CC       ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by 4-aminopyridine (4-AP),
CC       dendrotoxin (DTX) and charybdotoxin (CTX), but not by
CC       tetraethylammonium (TEA) (By similarity). Inhibited by
CC       tityustoxin-K alpha (TsTX-Kalpha), a toxin that is highly specific
CC       for KCNA2 (By similarity). Inhibited by maurotoxin
CC       (PubMed:12527813). Inhibited by kappaM conotoxins kappaM-RIIIJ and
CC       kappaM-RIIIK (By similarity). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P16389,
CC       ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P63142, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12527813}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         Note=Homotetrameric channels activate rapidly, i.e within a few
CC         msec, but inactivation is very slow, with only a marginal
CC         decrease in conductance over several seconds. The voltage-
CC         dependence of activation and inactivation and other channel
CC         characteristics vary depending on the experimental conditions,
CC         the expression system, post-translational modifications and the
CC         presence or absence of ancillary subunits. For the activation of
CC         homotetrameric channels expressed in Chinese hamster ovary (CHO)
CC         cells, the voltage at half-maximal amplitude is about -37 mV.
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20696761};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer and heterotetramer with other channel-
CC       forming alpha subunits, such as KCNA1, KCNA4, KCNA5, KCNA6 and
CC       KCNA7 (PubMed:8361541, PubMed:9852577, PubMed:23864368). Channel
CC       activity is regulated by interaction with beta subunits, including
CC       KCNAB1 and KCNAB2 (By similarity). Identified in a complex with
CC       KCNA1 and KCNAB2 (By similarity). Identified in a complex with
CC       KCNA5 and KCNAB1 (By similarity). Identified in a complex with
CC       KCNA4 and FYN (By similarity). Interacts with PTK2B (By
CC       similarity). Interacts (via C-terminus) with CTTN (By similarity).
CC       Interacts with ADAM22 (By similarity). Interacts with CNTNAP2 (By
CC       similarity). Interacts (via C-terminus) with the PDZ domains of
CC       DLG1, DLG2 and DLG4 (By similarity). Interacts (via N-terminal
CC       cytoplasmic domain) with RHOA (GTP-bound form); this regulates
CC       channel activity by reducing location at the cell surface in
CC       response to CHRM1 activation (PubMed:9635436). Interacts with DRD2
CC       (PubMed:21233214). Interacts with SIGMAR1; cocaine consumption
CC       leads to increased interaction (PubMed:23332758).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P16389, ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P63142,
CC       ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q09081, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17634333,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21233214, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23332758,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8361541, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9635436,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9852577, ECO:0000305,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:23864368}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q60598:Cttn; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-644033, EBI-397955;
CC       O55242:Sigmar1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-644033, EBI-1557700;
CC       Q9R0C9:Sigmar1 (xeno); NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-644033, EBI-1557826;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12527813,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18509034, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20696761,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23332758, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23864368}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P63142}. Membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23332758, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8361541,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9852577}. Cell projection, axon
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18509034, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21233214,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8046438, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8361541}. Cell
CC       junction, synapse {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P63142}. Endoplasmic
CC       reticulum membrane {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P63142}. Cell
CC       projection, lamellipodium membrane {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P63142}.
CC       Cell junction, synapse, synaptosome {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21233214}.
CC       Cell junction, synapse, presynaptic cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21233214}. Cell projection, dendrite
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8046438}. Perikaryon
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8046438}. Cell junction, paranodal septate
CC       junction {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25378149}. Note=KCNA2 by itself is
CC       detected both at the endoplasmic reticulum and at the cell
CC       membrane. Coexpression with KCNA4 or with beta subunits promotes
CC       expression at the cell membrane. Coexpression with KCNA1 inhibits
CC       cell surface expression (By similarity). Cocaine-induced
CC       interaction with SIGMAR1 increases expression at the cell surface
CC       (PubMed:23332758). In myelinated peripheral axons, clustered in
CC       the juxtaparadonal region and at an internodal line located along
CC       the mesaxon and below the Schmidt-Lanterman incisures
CC       (PubMed:25378149). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P63142,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23332758, ECO:0000269|PubMed:25378149}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in brain (PubMed:17634333). Detected
CC       in cerebellum (PubMed:20696761). Detected in mitral cells in the
CC       olfactory bulb (PubMed:8046438). Detected in cochlea
CC       (PubMed:23864368). Detected in cerebellum, particularly in the
CC       basket cell axon plexus and in the terminal regions around
CC       Purkinje cells (PubMed:8361541, PubMed:8046438, PubMed:18760366).
CC       Detected in juxtaparanodal regions in sciatic nerve
CC       (PubMed:22649228). Detected in Schwann cells from sciatic nerve
CC       (PubMed:9852577). Detected in dopamine neurons in substantia nigra
CC       (PubMed:21233214). Detected in large myelinated fibers in
CC       juxtaparanodes in the CA3 and CA1 areas of the hippocampus
CC       (PubMed:8046438, PubMed:18760366). Detected in brain, in punctae
CC       on fiber tracts in brain stem and spinal cord, and on axons in the
CC       juxtaparanodal regions of the node of Ranvier (at protein level)
CC       (PubMed:8361541). Detected in dopamine neurons in the midbrain
CC       (PubMed:21233214). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17634333,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18760366, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20696761,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22649228, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23864368,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8046438, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8361541,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9852577}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Detected at low levels in brainstem from
CC       neonates; increases tenfold during the first 29 days after birth.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17634333}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The cytoplasmic N-terminus is important for
CC       tetramerization. Interactions between the different subunits
CC       modulate the gating characteristics (By similarity). Besides, the
CC       cytoplasmic N-terminal domain mediates interaction with RHOA and
CC       thus is required for RHOA-mediated endocytosis (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P63142}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The transmembrane segment S4 functions as voltage-sensor
CC       and is characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids
CC       at every third position. Channel opening and closing is effected
CC       by a conformation change that affects the position and orientation
CC       of the voltage-sensor paddle formed by S3 and S4 within the
CC       membrane. A transmembrane electric field that is positive inside
CC       would push the positively charged S4 segment outwards, thereby
CC       opening the pore, while a field that is negative inside would pull
CC       the S4 segment inwards and close the pore. Changes in the position
CC       and orientation of S4 are then transmitted to the activation gate
CC       formed by the inner helix bundle via the S4-S5 linker region.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P63142}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated on tyrosine residues; phosphorylation
CC       increases in response to ischemia (By similarity). Phosphorylated
CC       on tyrosine residues by activated PTK2B/PYK2 (By similarity).
CC       Phosphorylation on tyrosine residues suppresses ion channel
CC       activity (By similarity). Phosphorylated on tyrosine residues in
CC       response to CHRM1 activation; this abolishes interaction with
CC       CTTN. This is probably due to endocytosis of the phosphorylated
CC       channel subunits (By similarity). Phosphorylated on serine
CC       residues in response to increased cAMP levels; phosphorylation is
CC       apparently not catalyzed by PKA (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P63142}.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylated, with complex, sialylated N-glycans.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P63142}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Pups are born at the expected Mendelian rate
CC       and appear normal during the first 14 days after birth. Starting
CC       at 14 to 17 days after birth, mice exhibit susceptibility to
CC       generalized seizures, followed by full tonic extension, which in
CC       mice often results in fatal apne. The average lifespan is 17 days;
CC       none survive more than 28 days (PubMed:17925011, PubMed:17634333).
CC       At P17 seizures are very rare and abnormal electroencephalograph
CC       activity is only present during the seizure. P17 pups have
CC       significantly less non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep (-23%) and
CC       significantly more waking (+21%) than wild-type siblings with no
CC       change in rapid eye movement (REM) sleep time. The decrease in
CC       NREM sleep is due to an increase in the number of waking episodes,
CC       with no change in number or duration of sleep episodes
CC       (PubMed:17925011). Auditory neurons from the medial nucleus of the
CC       trapezoid body in brain stem are hypoexcitable and fire fewer
CC       action potentials than wild-type neurons with significantly
CC       smaller threshold current amplitudes (PubMed:17634333). In the
CC       inner ear, spiral ganglion neurons display a hyperpolarized
CC       resting membrane potential, increased excitability and increased
CC       outward potassium currents; this might be because normally
CC       channels there are heterotetramers formed by KCNA2 and KCNA4, so
CC       the loss of KCNA2 changes channel characteristics
CC       (PubMed:23864368). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17634333,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17925011, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23864368}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Mutagenesis with N-ethyl-N-nitrosourea (ENU) lead
CC       to the discovery of the Pingu (Pgu) phenotype. At P21,
CC       heterozygous mice are clearly smaller than wild-type and have
CC       abnormal gait with a higher stance and splayed hind limbs.
CC       Homozygous mice are even smaller, and about half of them die
CC       between P15 and P35. Mutant mice have difficulty staing on a
CC       rotating rod and perform poorly in a beam-walking test, where they
CC       display flattened posture, severe tremors, myoclonic jerks and
CC       ataxic movement. These symptoms are alleviated by a drug used to
CC       treat cerebellar ataxia. Measurements with Purkinje cells from
CC       cerebellar brain slices show increased frequency and amplitude of
CC       spontaneous inhibitory postsynaptic currents.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20696761}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The delay or D-type current observed in hippocampus
CC       pyramidal neurons is probably mediated by potassium channels
CC       containing KCNA2 plus KCNA1 or other family members. It is
CC       activated at about -50 mV, i.e. below the action potential
CC       threshold, and is characterized by slow inactivation, extremely
CC       slow recovery from inactivation, sensitivity to dendrotoxin (DTX)
CC       and to 4-aminopyridine (4-AP). {ECO:0000305|PubMed:17917103}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. A (Shaker)
CC       (TC 1.A.1.2) subfamily. Kv1.2/KCNA2 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

ID   KCNG4_HUMAN             Reviewed;         519 AA.
AC   Q8TDN1; Q96H24;
DT   28-NOV-2002, integrated into UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot.
DT   01-JUN-2002, sequence version 1.
DT   22-NOV-2017, entry version 149.
DE   RecName: Full=Potassium voltage-gated channel subfamily G member 4;
DE   AltName: Full=Voltage-gated potassium channel subunit Kv6.4;
GN   Name=KCNG4; Synonyms=KCNG3;
OS   Homo sapiens (Human).
OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Chordata; Craniata; Vertebrata; Euteleostomi;
OC   Mammalia; Eutheria; Euarchontoglires; Primates; Haplorrhini;
OC   Catarrhini; Hominidae; Homo.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=9606;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA] (ISOFORM 1).
RC   TISSUE=Brain;
RX   PubMed=12060745; DOI=10.1073/pnas.122617999;
RA   Ottschytsch N., Raes A., Van Hoorick D., Snyders D.J.;
RT   "Obligatory heterotetramerization of three previously uncharacterized
RT   Kv channel alpha-subunits identified in the human genome.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 99:7986-7991(2002).
RN   [2]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA] (ISOFORM 2).
RC   TISSUE=Muscle;
RX   PubMed=15489334; DOI=10.1101/gr.2596504;
RG   The MGC Project Team;
RT   "The status, quality, and expansion of the NIH full-length cDNA
RT   project: the Mammalian Gene Collection (MGC).";
RL   Genome Res. 14:2121-2127(2004).
RN   [3]
RP   FUNCTION, SUBUNIT, INTERACTION WITH KCNB1, AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=19074135; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M808786200;
RA   Mederos y Schnitzler M., Rinne S., Skrobek L., Renigunta V.,
RA   Schlichthorl G., Derst C., Gudermann T., Daut J., Preisig-Muller R.;
RT   "Mutation of histidine 105 in the T1 domain of the potassium channel
RT   Kv2.1 disrupts heteromerization with Kv6.3 and Kv6.4.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 284:4695-4704(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Potassium channel subunit that does not form functional
CC       channels by itself. Can form functional heterotetrameric channels
CC       with KCNB1; modulates the delayed rectifier voltage-gated
CC       potassium channel activation and deactivation rates of KCNB1
CC       (PubMed:19074135). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19074135}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer with KCNB1 (PubMed:19074135).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19074135}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19074135};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}. Note=Has to be
CC       associated with KCNB1 or possibly another partner to get inserted
CC       in the plasma membrane. Colocalizes with KCNB1 at the plasma
CC       membrane. Remains intracellular in the absence of KCNB1
CC       (PubMed:19074135). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19074135}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q8TDN1-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q8TDN1-2; Sequence=VSP_001029, VSP_001030;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Highly expressed in brain, and at lower levels
CC       in liver, small intestine and colon.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The transmembrane segment S4 functions as voltage-sensor
CC       and is characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids
CC       at every third position. Channel opening and closing is effected
CC       by a conformation change that affects the position and orientation
CC       of the voltage-sensor paddle formed by S3 and S4 within the
CC       membrane. A transmembrane electric field that is positive inside
CC       would push the positively charged S4 segment outwards, thereby
CC       opening the pore, while a field that is negative inside would pull
CC       the S4 segment inwards and close the pore. Changes in the position
CC       and orientation of S4 are then transmitted to the activation gate
CC       formed by the inner helix bundle via the S4-S5 linker region.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P63142}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. G (TC
CC       1.A.1.2) subfamily. Kv6.4/KCNG4 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   INTERACTION WITH UNC-101, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, TISSUE SPECIFICITY,
RP   DOMAIN, AND MUTAGENESIS OF 217-TRP--GLU-221; 217-TRP--ILE-219;
RP   ILE-219; 496-GLU--LEU-500 AND 497-GLN--MET-498.

RA   Zhou X., Zeng J., Ouyang C., Luo Q., Yu M., Yang Z., Wang H., Shen K.,
RA   Shi A.;
RT   "A novel bipartite UNC-101/AP-1 mu1 binding signal mediates KVS-
RT   4/Kv2.1 somatodendritic distribution in Caenorhabditis elegans.";

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-gated potassium channel that mediates
CC       transmembrane potassium transport in excitable membranes.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P63142}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer or heterotetramer (Probable). Interacts with
CC       unc-101 (via N-terminus); which targets kvs-4 to dendrites
CC       (PubMed:26762178). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26762178, ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000255}. Perikaryon
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26762178}. Cell projection, axon
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26762178}. Cell projection, dendrite
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26762178}. Note=Association with unc-101 is
CC       required for dendritic localization.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:26762178}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=a {ECO:0000312|WormBase:Y48A6B.6a};
CC         IsoId=Q9XXD1-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=b {ECO:0000312|WormBase:Y48A6B.6b};
CC         IsoId=Q9XXD1-2; Sequence=VSP_059007, VSP_059008;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in the cholinergic motor neuron DA9,
CC       mechanosensory neurons ALM and PLM, and the interneuron PVPL.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26762178}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The transmembrane segment S4 functions as voltage-sensor
CC       and is characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids
CC       at every third position. Channel opening and closing is effected
CC       by a conformation change that affects the position and orientation
CC       of the voltage-sensor paddle formed by S3 and S4 within the
CC       membrane. A transmembrane electric field that is positive inside
CC       would push the positively charged S4 segment outwards, thereby
CC       opening the pore, while a field that is negative inside would pull
CC       the S4 segment inwards and close the pore. Changes in the position
CC       and orientation of S4 are then transmitted to the activation gate
CC       formed by the inner helix bundle via the S4-S5 linker region.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P63142}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EQMIL and WNIIE motifs are required for dendritic
CC       localization. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26762178}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. B (Shab) (TC
CC       1.A.1.2) subfamily. Kv2.2/KCNB2 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

DE   RecName: Full=Potassium channel HX13_20290;
GN   ORFNames=HX13_20290 {ECO:0000312|EMBL:KFF73457.1};
OS   Chryseobacterium sp. (strain P1-3).
OC   Bacteria; Bacteroidetes; Flavobacteriia; Flavobacteriales;
OC   Flavobacteriaceae; Chryseobacterium.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=1517683;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE GENOMIC DNA].
RC   STRAIN=P1-3 {ECO:0000312|EMBL:KFF73457.1};

RN   [2]
RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=26317472; DOI=10.1016/j.cell.2015.08.002;
RA   Cang C., Aranda K., Seo Y.J., Gasnier B., Ren D.;
RT   "TMEM175 is an organelle K(+) channel regulating lysosomal function.";
RL   Cell 162:1101-1112(2015).
RN   [3]
RP   SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=28723891; DOI=10.1038/nature23269;
RA   Lee C., Guo J., Zeng W., Kim S., She J., Cang C., Ren D., Jiang Y.;
RT   "The lysosomal potassium channel TMEM175 adopts a novel tetrameric
RT   architecture.";
RL   Nature 547:472-475(2017).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Potassium channel. {ECO:0000305|PubMed:26317472}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer (PubMed:28723891).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:28723891}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000255}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The six transmembrane regions are tightly packed within
CC       each subunit without undergoing domain swapping. Transmembranes
CC       TM1-TM3 are positioned on the inner circle of the channel tetramer
CC       and participate in inter-subunit interactions that are central to
CC       the assembly of the ion conduction pore. The RxxxFSD motif within
CC       transmembrane TM1 coordinates a network of specific inter- and
CC       intra-subunit interactions with other conserved residues on TM2
CC       and TM3 and plays a key role in the tetrameric assembly of the
CC       channel. Transmembrane TM4-TM6 are positioned on the periphery of
CC       the channel and do not contribute contacts with neighboring
CC       subunits. Transmembranes TM1 and TM2 are linked by an extended
CC       strand-like tail and two short helices (H1 and H2) which protrude
CC       outwards from the main body of the transmembrane domain and
CC       enclose the external open entrance of the ion conduction pore in
CC       the channel tetramer. Transmembrane TM1 forms the pore-lining
CC       inner helix at the center of the channel, creating an hourglass-
CC       shaped ion permeation pathway in the channel tetramer. Three
CC       hydrophobic residues on the C-terminal half of the TM1 helix form
CC       a bottleneck along the ion conduction pathway and serve as the
CC       selectivity filter of the channel. Ile-16 is probably responsible
CC       for channel selectivity. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:K9UJK2}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TMEM175 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

DE   RecName: Full=Potassium voltage-gated channel subfamily S member 1;
DE   AltName: Full=Delayed-rectifier K(+) channel alpha subunit 1;
GN   Name=KCNS1;
OS   Otolemur garnettii (Small-eared galago) (Garnett's greater bushbaby).
OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Chordata; Craniata; Vertebrata; Euteleostomi;
OC   Mammalia; Eutheria; Euarchontoglires; Primates; Strepsirrhini;
OC   Lorisiformes; Galagidae; Otolemur.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=30611;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [GENOMIC DNA].
RX   PubMed=17267810; DOI=10.1101/gr.6004607;
RG   NISC comparative sequencing program;
RA   Hurle B., Swanson W., Green E.D.;
RT   "Comparative sequence analyses reveal rapid and divergent evolutionary
RT   changes of the WFDC locus in the primate lineage.";
RL   Genome Res. 17:276-286(2007).
RN   [2]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE GENOMIC DNA].
RG   The Broad Institute Genome Sequencing Platform;
RA   Di Palma F., Johnson J., Lander E.S., Lindblad-Toh K., Jaffe D.B.,
RA   Gnerre S., MacCallum I., Przybylski D., Ribeiro F.J., Burton J.N.,
RA   Walker B.J., Sharpe T., Hall G.;
RT   "Version 3 of the genome sequence of Otolemur garnettii(Bushbaby).";
RL   Submitted (MAR-2011) to the EMBL/GenBank/DDBJ databases.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Potassium channel subunit that does not form functional
CC       channels by itself. Can form functional heterotetrameric channels
CC       with KCNB1 and KCNB2; modulates the delayed rectifier voltage-
CC       gated potassium channel activation and deactivation rates of KCNB1
CC       and KCNB2. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O35173}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heteromultimer with KCNB1 and KCNB2. Does not form
CC       homomultimers. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O35173}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O35173}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O35173}. Note=May not reach the plasma
CC       membrane but remain in an intracellular compartment in the absence
CC       of KCNB1 or KCNB2. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O35173}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The transmembrane segment S4 functions as voltage-sensor
CC       and is characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids
CC       at every third position. Channel opening and closing is effected
CC       by a conformation change that affects the position and orientation
CC       of the voltage-sensor paddle formed by S3 and S4 within the
CC       membrane. A transmembrane electric field that is positive inside
CC       would push the positively charged S4 segment outwards, thereby
CC       opening the pore, while a field that is negative inside would pull
CC       the S4 segment inwards and close the pore. Changes in the position
CC       and orientation of S4 are then transmitted to the activation gate
CC       formed by the inner helix bundle via the S4-S5 linker region.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P63142}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. S (TC
CC       1.A.1.2) subfamily. Kv9.1/KCNS1 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [3]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (3.4 ANGSTROMS) OF 330-1063, FUNCTION, AND PH
RP   DEPENDENCE.
RX   PubMed=23129643; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1215078109;
RA   Leonetti M.D., Yuan P., Hsiung Y., Mackinnon R.;
RT   "Functional and structural analysis of the human SLO3 pH- and voltage-
RT   gated K+ channel.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 109:19274-19279(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Testis-specific potassium channel activated by both
CC       intracellular pH and membrane voltage that mediates export of
CC       K(+). May represent the primary spermatozoan K(+) current. In
CC       contrast to KCNMA1/SLO1, it is not activated by Ca(2+) or Mg(2+).
CC       Critical for fertility. May play an important role in sperm
CC       osmoregulation required for the acquisition of normal morphology
CC       and motility when faced with osmotic challenges, such as those
CC       experienced after mixing with seminal fluid and entry into the
CC       vagina. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23129643}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer; which constitutes the calcium-activated
CC       potassium channel. May interact with LRRC52; this interaction may
CC       change channel gating properties, such as shifting gating to more
CC       negative potentials at a given pH. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000250}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Testis-specific. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9452476}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The S4 segment, which is characterized by a series of
CC       positively charged amino acids at every third position, is part of
CC       the voltage-sensor. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The pore-forming domain (also referred as P region) is
CC       imbedded into the membrane, and forms the selectivity filter of
CC       the pore. It contains the signature sequence of potassium channels
CC       that displays selectivity to potassium (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The RCK N-terminal domain mediates the
CC       homotetramerization, thereby promoting the assembly of monomers
CC       into functional potassium channel. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The C-terminal cytosolic region confers the pH-dependence.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. Calcium-
CC       activated (TC 1.A.1.3) subfamily. KCa5.1/KCNU1 sub-subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Pore-forming (alpha) subunit of voltage-gated inwardly
CC       rectifying potassium channel. Channel properties are modulated by
CC       cAMP and subunit assembly (By similarity). Regulates the movements
CC       of the male's copulatory spicules before and during male mating
CC       behavior (PubMed:12684455). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q12809,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12684455}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The potassium channel is composed of a homo- or
CC       heterotetrameric complex (PubMed:27916661). Interacts with dnj-1;
CC       dnj-1 chaperone promotes tetramerization (PubMed:27916661).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27916661}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q12809}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=10;

CC                                  VSP_058905;

ID   TM175_CHAP6             Reviewed;         203 AA.
AC   K9UJK2;
DT   25-OCT-2017, integrated into UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot.

DE   RecName: Full=Potassium channel Cha6605_3372 {ECO:0000305};
DE   AltName: Full=Transmembrane protein 175 {ECO:0000303|PubMed:28723891};
DE            Short=CmTMEM175 {ECO:0000303|PubMed:28723891};
GN   ORFNames=Cha6605_3372 {ECO:0000312|EMBL:AFY94374.1};
OS   Chamaesiphon minutus (strain ATCC 27169 / PCC 6605).

RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE GENOMIC DNA].
RC   STRAIN=ATCC 27169 / PCC 6605;
RG   US DOE Joint Genome Institute;
RA   Gugger M., Coursin T., Rippka R., Tandeau De Marsac N., Huntemann M.,
RA   Wei C.-L., Han J., Detter J.C., Han C., Tapia R., Chen A.,

RN   [2]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (3.3 ANGSTROMS) OF 7-203, FUNCTION, TOPOLOGY,
RP   SUBUNIT, DOMAIN, AND MUTAGENESIS OF ILE-23.
RX   PubMed=28723891; DOI=10.1038/nature23269;
RA   Lee C., Guo J., Zeng W., Kim S., She J., Cang C., Ren D., Jiang Y.;
RT   "The lysosomal potassium channel TMEM175 adopts a novel tetrameric
RT   architecture.";
RL   Nature 547:472-475(2017).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Potassium channel (PubMed:28723891). The channel is
CC       permeable for K(+), Rb(+) and Cs(+), while it is unable to conduct
CC       Na(+) (PubMed:28723891). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:28723891}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer (PubMed:28723891).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:28723891}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000255}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:28723891}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: In contrast to canonical tetrameric potassium channels,
CC       lacks the TVGYG selectivity filter motif and presents a completely
CC       different structure. The six transmembrane regions are tightly
CC       packed within each subunit without undergoing domain swapping.
CC       Transmembranes TM1-TM3 are positioned on the inner circle of the
CC       channel tetramer and participate in inter-subunit interactions
CC       that are central to the assembly of the ion conduction pore. The
CC       RxxxFSD motif within transmembrane TM1 coordinates a network of
CC       specific inter- and intra-subunit interactions with other
CC       conserved residues on TM2 and TM3 and plays a key role in the
CC       tetrameric assembly of the channel. Transmembrane TM4-TM6 are
CC       positioned on the periphery of the channel and do not contribute
CC       contacts with neighboring subunits. Transmembranes TM1 and TM2 are
CC       linked by an extended strand-like tail and two short helices (H1
CC       and H2) which protrude outwards from the main body of the
CC       transmembrane domain and enclose the external open entrance of the
CC       ion conduction pore in the channel tetramer. Transmembrane TM3 is
CC       bent into two segments (TM3a and TM3b) due to the presence of a
CC       conserved proline (Pro-102). Transmembrane TM1 forms the pore-
CC       lining inner helix at the center of the channel, creating an
CC       hourglass-shaped ion permeation pathway in the channel tetramer.
CC       Three hydrophobic residues (Ile-23, Leu-27 and Leu-30) on the C-
CC       terminal half of the TM1 helix form a bottleneck along the ion
CC       conduction pathway and serve as the selectivity filter of the
CC       channel. Ile-23 is probably responsible for channel selectivity.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:28723891}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TMEM175 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [22]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (3.4 ANGSTROMS) OF 23-288 IN COMPLEX WITH
RP   POTASSIUM IONS, FUNCTION, SUBUNIT, DISULFIDE BOND, TOPOLOGY, AND
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=22282804; DOI=10.1126/science.1213274;
RA   Miller A.N., Long S.B.;
RT   "Crystal structure of the human two-pore domain potassium channel
RT   K2P1.";
RL   Science 335:432-436(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Ion channel that contributes to passive transmembrane
CC       potassium transport and to the regulation of the resting membrane
CC       potential in brain astrocytes, but also in kidney and in other
CC       tissues (PubMed:15820677, PubMed:21653227). Forms dimeric channels
CC       through which potassium ions pass in accordance with their
CC       electrochemical gradient. The channel is selective for K(+) ions
CC       at physiological potassium concentrations and at neutral pH, but
CC       becomes permeable to Na(+) at subphysiological K(+) levels and
CC       upon acidification of the extracellular medium (PubMed:21653227,
CC       PubMed:22431633). The homodimer has very low potassium channel
CC       activity, when expressed in heterologous systems, and can function
CC       as weakly inward rectifying potassium channel (PubMed:8605869,
CC       PubMed:8978667, PubMed:15820677, PubMed:21653227, PubMed:22431633,
CC       PubMed:23169818, PubMed:25001086). Channel activity is modulated
CC       by activation of serotonin receptors (By similarity).
CC       Heterodimeric channels containing KCNK1 and KCNK2 have much higher
CC       activity, and may represent the predominant form in astrocytes (By
CC       similarity). Heterodimeric channels containing KCNK1 and KCNK3 or
CC       KCNK9 have much higher activity (PubMed:23169818). Heterodimeric
CC       channels formed by KCNK1 and KCNK9 may contribute to halothane-
CC       sensitive currents (PubMed:23169818). Mediates outward rectifying
CC       potassium currents in dentate gyrus granule cells and contributes
CC       to the regulation of their resting membrane potential (By
CC       similarity). Contributes to the regulation of action potential
CC       firing in dentate gyrus granule cells and down-regulates their
CC       intrinsic excitability (By similarity). In astrocytes, the
CC       heterodimer formed by KCNK1 and KCNK2 is required for rapid
CC       glutamate release in response to activation of G-protein coupled
CC       receptors, such as F2R and CNR1 (By similarity). Required for
CC       normal ion and water transport in the kidney (By similarity).
CC       Contributes to the regulation of the resting membrane potential of
CC       pancreatic beta cells (By similarity). The low channel activity of
CC       homodimeric KCNK1 may be due to sumoylation (PubMed:15820677,
CC       PubMed:20498050, PubMed:23169818). The low channel activity may be
CC       due to rapid internalization from the cell membrane and retention
CC       in recycling endosomes (PubMed:19959478).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O08581, ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9Z2T2,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15820677, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17693262,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19959478, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20498050,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21653227, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22282804,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22431633, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23169818,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25001086, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8605869,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8978667}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by Ba(2+) ions and quinidine
CC       (PubMed:8605869). Inhibited by quinine (PubMed:8605869,
CC       PubMed:21653227). Is slightly inhibited by 10 mM
CC       tetraethylammonium (TEA), and only marginally inhibited by 4-
CC       aminopyridine, charybdotoxin and dendrotoxin (PubMed:8605869).
CC       Lowering the extracellular pH to below 6.5 transiently activates
CC       the channel, and then inhibits channel activity (PubMed:15820677,
CC       PubMed:22431633). Inhibited when the intracellular pH is decreased
CC       down to pH 6.0, but this may be due to indirect effects
CC       (PubMed:8605869). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15820677,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21653227, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22431633,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8605869}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         Note=Has a unit conductance of 34 pS. Both activation and
CC         channel closure are very rapid. Is not voltage-gated. The
CC         relationship between voltage and current is nearly linear. Has a
CC         mean open time of 0.3 msec at a membrane potential of -80 mV,
CC         and 1.9 msec at +80 mV (PubMed:8605869).
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19959478, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8605869};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer; disulfide-linked (PubMed:8978667,
CC       PubMed:22282804). Heterodimer with KCNK2; disulfide-linked (By
CC       similarity). In astrocytes, forms mostly heterodimeric potassium
CC       channels with KCNK2, with only a minor proportion of functional
CC       channels containing homodimeric KCNK1 (By similarity). Interacts
CC       with KCNK3 and KCNK9, forming functional heterodimeric channels
CC       (PubMed:23169818). Interacts with GNG4 (By similarity). Identified
CC       in a complex with PSD and ARF6; interacts only with PSD that is
CC       bound to ARF6 (By similarity). Interacts with UBE2I
CC       (PubMed:15820677). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O08581,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15820677, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22282804,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23169818, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8978667}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-3914675, EBI-3914675;
CC       A8MQ03:CYSRT1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-3914675, EBI-3867333;
CC       P63165:SUMO1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-3914675, EBI-80140;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15820677,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17693262, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20498050,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21653227, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22282804,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22431633, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23169818,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25001086, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8605869,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8978667}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22282804, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8978667,
CC       ECO:0000305}. Recycling endosome {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19959478}.
CC       Cell junction, synapse {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9Z2T2}. Cytoplasmic
CC       vesicle {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O08581}. Perikaryon
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O08581}. Cell projection, dendrite
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O08581}. Cell projection
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O08581}. Apical cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21964404}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000305}. Note=The heterodimer with KCNK2 is detected at the
CC       astrocyte cell membrane. Not detected at the astrocyte cell
CC       membrane when KCNK2 is absent. Detected on neuronal cell bodies,
CC       and to a lesser degree on neuronal cell projections. Detected on
CC       hippocampus dentate gyrus granule cell bodies and to a lesser
CC       degree on proximal dendrites. Detected in synaptic membranes.
CC       Detected at the apical cell membrane in stria vascularis in the
CC       cochlea. Detected at the apical cell membrane of vestibular dark
CC       cells situated between the crista and the utricle in the inner
CC       ear. Detected at the apical cell membrane in kidney proximal
CC       tubule segment S1 and in subapical compartments in segments S1, S2
CC       and S3. Predominantly in cytoplasmic structures in kidney distal
CC       convoluted tubules and collecting ducts (By similarity). Detected
CC       at the apical cell membrane of bronchial epithelial cells
CC       (PubMed:21964404). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O08581,
CC       ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9Z2T2, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21964404}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in bronchial epithelial cells
CC       (PubMed:21964404). Detected in heart left atrium and left
CC       ventricle (PubMed:17478540). Detected in cardiac myocytes (at
CC       protein level) (PubMed:21653227). Widely expressed with high
CC       levels in heart, brain and kidney, and lower levels in colon,
CC       ovary, placenta, lung and liver (PubMed:8605869, PubMed:9362344).
CC       Highly expressed in cerebellum, and detected at lower levels in
CC       amygdala, caudate nucleus, brain cortex, hippocampus, putamen,
CC       substantia nigra, thalamus, dorsal root ganglion, spinal cord,
CC       pituitary, heart, kidney, lung, placenta, pancreas, stomach, small
CC       intestine, uterus and prostate (PubMed:11165377). Detected in
CC       right and left heart ventricle and atrium, and in heart Purkinje
CC       fibers (PubMed:17478540). Detected in bronchial epithelial cells
CC       (PubMed:21964404). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11165377,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17478540, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21653227,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21964404, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8605869,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9362344}.
CC   -!- PTM: Sumoylation is controversial. Sumoylated by UBE2I
CC       (PubMed:15820677). Not sumoylated when expressed in xenopus
CC       oocytes or mammalian cells (PubMed:17693262). Sumoylation
CC       inactivates the channel, but does not interfere with expression at
CC       the cell membrane (PubMed:15820677). Sumoylation of a single
CC       subunit is sufficient to silence the dimeric channel
CC       (PubMed:20498050, PubMed:23169818). Sumoylation of KCNK1 is
CC       sufficient to silence heterodimeric channels formed by KCNK1 and
CC       KCNK3 or KCNK9 (PubMed:23169818). Desumoylated by SENP1; this
CC       activates the channel (PubMed:15820677, PubMed:20498050,
CC       PubMed:23169818). Desumoylated by SENP1; this strongly increases
CC       halothane-mediated activation of heterodimeric channels formed
CC       with KCNK9 (PubMed:23169818). SENP1 treatment has no effect
CC       (PubMed:17693262). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15820677,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17693262, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20498050,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23169818}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: When the external K(+) concentration is lowered to
CC       subphysiological levels, it takes several minutes till the channel
CC       has reached a new, stable state characterized by increased Na(+)
CC       permeability (PubMed:21653227). Likewise, when the external pH is
CC       lowered to values below 6.5, it takes several minutes till the
CC       channel has reached a new, stable state characterized by increased
CC       Na(+) permeability (PubMed:22431633). When raising the K(+)
CC       concentration back to 5 mM, it takes 40 to 70 minutes for the
CC       channel to regain its original selectivity for K(+)
CC       (PubMed:21653227). Likewise, it takes more that 25 minutes for the
CC       channel to regain its original K(+) selectivity when the pH is
CC       raised back to 7.4 (PubMed:22431633).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21653227, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22431633}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the two pore domain potassium channel (TC
CC       1.A.1.8) family. {ECO:0000305}.

FT                                {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8978667}.
FT   DISULFID     69     69       Interchain. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22282804,
FT                                ECO:0000269|PubMed:8978667}.
FT   CROSSLNK    274    274       Glycyl lysine isopeptide (Lys-Gly)
FT                                (interchain with G-Cter in SUMO).
FT                                {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15820677,
FT                                ECO:0000269|PubMed:20498050}.
FT   MUTAGEN      69     69       C->A: Abolishes channel activity and
FT                                formation of disulfide-linked homodimers.
FT                                {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8978667}.
FT   MUTAGEN      95     95       N->A: Abolishes N-glycosylation.
FT                                {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8978667}.
FT   MUTAGEN     108    109       LF->FY: Impairs selectivity for K(+) ions
FT                                and increases permeability to Na(+) ions,
FT                                both at pH 7.4 and at pH 6.
FT                                {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22431633}.
FT   MUTAGEN     118    118       T->I: Abolishes change in ion selectivity
FT                                in the presence of subphysiological K(+)
FT                                levels. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21653227}.
FT   MUTAGEN     122    122       H->K: Increases channel activity, and has
FT                                only a minor effect on the inhibition by
FT                                acidification of the extracellular
FT                                medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22431633}.
FT   MUTAGEN     122    122       H->N: Decreases channel activity and
FT                                abolishes inhibition by acidification of
FT                                the extracellular medium.
FT                                {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15820677,
FT                                ECO:0000269|PubMed:20498050,
FT                                ECO:0000269|PubMed:22431633}.
FT   MUTAGEN     146    146       L->A,V: Does not increase the low
FT                                intrinsic channel activity.
FT                                {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25001086}.
FT   MUTAGEN     146    146       L->D: Increases channel activity.
FT                                {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22431633,
FT                                ECO:0000269|PubMed:25001086}.
FT   MUTAGEN     146    146       L->N,T: Increases channel activity.
FT                                {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25001086}.
FT   MUTAGEN     146    146       L->S: Increases channel activity.
FT                                Strongly increases channel activity; when
FT                                associated with S-261.
FT                                {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25001086}.
FT   MUTAGEN     161    161       T->A: No effect on channel activity.
FT                                {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8605869}.
FT   MUTAGEN     228    228       L->F: No effect on selectivity for K(+)
FT                                ions. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22431633}.
FT   MUTAGEN     231    231       Y->F: Strongly decreases activity of
FT                                homodimeric channels and of heterodimeric
FT                                channels formed with KCNK3 and with
FT                                KCNK9. No effect on location at the cell
FT                                membrane. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23169818}.
FT   MUTAGEN     250    250       T->L: Slighly decreases the increased
FT                                permeability to Na(+) ions at pH 6.
FT                                {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22431633}.
FT   MUTAGEN     261    261       L->D,N: Increases channel activity.
FT                                {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25001086}.
FT   MUTAGEN     261    261       L->S: Increases channel activity.
FT                                Strongly increases channel activity; when
FT                                associated with S-146.
FT                                {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25001086}.
FT   MUTAGEN     274    274       K->A,C,D,Q,R: Converts the electrically
FT                                silent channel that is present at the
FT                                cell membrane to an active channel.
FT                                {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20498050}.
FT   MUTAGEN     274    274       K->E: Converts the electrically silent
FT                                channel that is present at the cell
FT                                membrane to an active channel. No effect
FT                                on retention in recycling endosomes.
FT                                {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15820677,
FT                                ECO:0000269|PubMed:17693262,
FT                                ECO:0000269|PubMed:19959478,

FT                                the cell membrane.

RN   [18]
RP   REVIEW.
RX   PubMed=25339226; DOI=10.1007/s00424-014-1631-y;
RA   Bichet D., Blin S., Feliciangeli S., Chatelain F.C., Bobak N.,
RA   Lesage F.;
RT   "Silent but not dumb: how cellular trafficking and pore gating
RT   modulate expression of TWIK1 and THIK2.";
RL   Pflugers Arch. 467:1121-1131(2015).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Ion channel that contributes to passive transmembrane
CC       potassium transport and to the regulation of the resting membrane
CC       potential in brain astrocytes, but also in kidney and in other
CC       tissues (PubMed:16847696, PubMed:22431633, PubMed:24368895). Forms
CC       dimeric channels through which potassium ions pass in accordance
CC       with their electrochemical gradient. The channel is selective for
CC       K(+) ions at physiological potassium concentrations and at neutral
CC       pH, but becomes permeable to Na(+) at subphysiological K(+) levels
CC       and upon acidification of the extracellular medium. The homodimer
CC       has very low potassium channel activity, when expressed in
CC       heterologous systems, and can function as weakly inward rectifying
CC       potassium channel (PubMed:9013852, PubMed:24496152). Channel
CC       activity is modulated by activation of serotonin receptors
CC       (PubMed:24368895). Heterodimeric channels containing KCNK1 and
CC       KCNK2 have much higher activity, and may represent the predominant
CC       form in astrocytes (PubMed:24496152). Heterodimeric channels
CC       containing KCNK1 and KCNK3 or KCNK9 have much higher activity.
CC       Heterodimeric channels formed by KCNK1 and KCNK9 may contribute to
CC       halothane-sensitive currents (By similarity). Mediates outward
CC       rectifying potassium currents in dentate gyrus granule cells and
CC       contributes to the regulation of their resting membrane potential
CC       (PubMed:25406588). Contributes to the regulation of action
CC       potential firing in dentate gyrus granule cells and down-regulates
CC       their intrinsic excitability (PubMed:25406588). In astrocytes, the
CC       heterodimer formed by KCNK1 and KCNK2 is required for rapid
CC       glutamate release in response to activation of G-protein coupled
CC       receptors, such as F2R and CNR1 (PubMed:24496152). Required for
CC       normal ion and water transport in the kidney (PubMed:16025300).
CC       Contributes to the regulation of the resting membrane potential of
CC       pancreatic beta cells (PubMed:22431633). The low channel activity
CC       of homodimeric KCNK1 may be due to sumoylation. The low channel
CC       activity may be due to rapid internalization from the cell
CC       membrane and retention in recycling endosomes (PubMed:15540117).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O00180, ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9Z2T2,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15540117, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16025300,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16847696, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22431633,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24368895, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24496152,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9013852}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by quinine, quinidine, barium, and
CC       internal acidification. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9013852,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:16847696}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         Note=Both activation and channel closure are very rapid. Is not
CC         voltage-gated (PubMed:22431633, PubMed:24496152). The
CC         relationship between voltage and current is nearly linear
CC         (PubMed:22431633, PubMed:24496152).
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22431633, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24496152,
CC         ECO:0000305};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer; disulfide-linked (PubMed:9013852). Heterodimer
CC       with KCNK2; disulfide-linked (PubMed:24496152). In astrocytes,
CC       forms mostly heterodimeric potassium channels with KCNK2, with
CC       only a minor proportion of functional channels containing
CC       homodimeric KCNK1 (By similarity). Interacts with KCNK3 and KCNK9,
CC       forming functional heterodimeric channels (By similarity).
CC       Interacts with GNG4 (PubMed:24496152). Identified in a complex
CC       with PSD and ARF6; interacts only with PSD that is bound to ARF6
CC       (PubMed:15540117). Interacts with UBE2I (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O00180, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15540117,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24496152, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9013852}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15540117,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19959478, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24368895,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24496152, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9013852}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}. Recycling endosome
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15540117}. Apical cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12855359, ECO:0000305|PubMed:16025300}.
CC       Cytoplasmic vesicle {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16025300,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24368895}. Perikaryon
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12855359, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17079103,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25406588}. Cell projection, dendrite
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25406588}. Cell projection
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17079103}. Cell junction, synapse
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9Z2T2}. Note=The heterodimer with KCNK2 is
CC       detected at the astrocyte cell membrane (PubMed:24496152). Not
CC       detected at the astrocyte cell membrane when KCNK2 is absent
CC       (PubMed:24496152). Detected on neuronal cell bodies, and to a
CC       lesser degree on neuronal cell projections (PubMed:12855359,
CC       PubMed:17079103). Detected on hippocampus dentate gyrus granule
CC       cell bodies and to a lesser degree on proximal dendrites
CC       (PubMed:25406588). Detected in synaptic membranes. Detected at the
CC       apical cell membrane in stria vascularis in the cochlea (By
CC       similarity). Detected at the apical cell membrane of vestibular
CC       dark cells situated between the crista and the utricle in the
CC       inner ear (PubMed:12855359). Detected at the apical cell membrane
CC       in stria vascularis in the cochlea (PubMed:12855359). Detected at
CC       the apical cell membrane in kidney proximal tubule segment S1 and
CC       in subapical compartments in segments S1, S2 and S3
CC       (PubMed:16025300). Predominantly in cytoplasmic structures in
CC       kidney distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts
CC       (PubMed:16025300). Predominantly in cytoplasmic structures in
CC       hippocampus astrocytes; only a minor proportion of the protein is
CC       present at the cell membrane (PubMed:24368895).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9Z2T2, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16025300,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17079103, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24368895,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24496152, ECO:0000269|PubMed:25406588}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in spiral ganglion neurons
CC       (PubMed:17079103). Detected in hippocampus CA1 and CA1 regions and
CC       in the molecular layer of the dentate gyrus (PubMed:24368895,
CC       PubMed:25406588). Detected on hippocampus astrocytes
CC       (PubMed:24368895, PubMed:24496152). Highly expressed in the stria
CC       vascularis in the cochlea (PubMed:12855359). Detected in pancreas
CC       islet beta cells (PubMed:22431633). Detected in kidney, at brush
CC       border membranes in proximal tubules and in cytoplasmic structures
CC       in distal convoluted tubules, thick ascending limbs and collecting
CC       ducts (at protein level) (PubMed:15540117, PubMed:16025300).
CC       Widely expressed. Detected in spiral ganglion cells
CC       (PubMed:17079103). Highest expression in brain, kidney, thyroid,
CC       salivary gland, adrenal gland, prostate, epididymis, uterus,
CC       placenta, colon and jejunum. Moderate expression in eyes,
CC       pituitary, pancreas, smooth muscle, testis and ovary. Very low
CC       levels in lung, aorta, liver, heart, skeletal muscle, thymus and
CC       spleen. In the brain, highest expression in cerebellar granule
CC       cells, brainstem, hippocampus and cerebral cortex
CC       (PubMed:18222039). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15540117,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16025300, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18222039,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22431633, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24368895,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25406588, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9013852,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9559671}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Detected at very low levels in the embyonic
CC       central nervous system (PubMed:9559671, PubMed:18222039). Detected
CC       as early as 7 days post conception (PubMed:9559671). Detected in
CC       dorsal root ganglia, hippocampus, olfactory epithelia and
CC       intestine at 19 dpc (PubMed:18222039). Expression in the brain
CC       increases strongly 3-8 days after birth, a period of intense
CC       postnatal brain development (PubMed:9559671, PubMed:18222039).
CC       Detected in dentate granule cells; expression levels show no
CC       significant variability during postnatal development
CC       (PubMed:18222039). Expression is higher in adults than in neonates
CC       (PubMed:9559671, PubMed:18222039). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18222039,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9559671}.
CC   -!- PTM: Sumoylation is controversial. Sumoylated by UBE2I. Not
CC       sumoylated when expressed in xenopus oocytes or mammalian cells.
CC       Sumoylation inactivates the channel, but does not interfere with
CC       expression at the cell membrane. Sumoylation of a single subunit
CC       is sufficient to silence the dimeric channel. Sumoylation of KCNK1
CC       is sufficient to silence heterodimeric channels formed by KCNK1
CC       and KCNK3 or KCNK9. Desumoylated by SENP1; this activates the
CC       channel. Desumoylated by SENP1; this strongly increases halothane-
CC       mediated activation of heterodimeric channels formed with KCNK9.
CC       SENP1 treatment has no effect. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O00180}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: No visible phenotype on standard chow,
CC       excepting a lower urinary flow rate (PubMed:16025300). Mice appear
CC       normal and are fertile (PubMed:24368895). When kept on a low
CC       phosphate diet, both wild-type and mutant mice show strongly
CC       reduced urinary phosphate secretion. Still, mutant mice display
CC       higher fractional urinary phosphate secretion relative to wild-
CC       type, leading to reduced inorganic phosphate levels in blood
CC       plasma. The impaired phosphate homeostasis seems to be due to
CC       indirect effects on the expression of other transporters, such as
CC       SLC34A1 and AQP2 (PubMed:16025300). Principal cells from kidney
CC       collecting duct are hyperpolarized, display reduced potassium
CC       conductance and strongly reduced quinidine-sensitive potassium
CC       channel activity (PubMed:16847696). Besides, collecting ducts from
CC       mutant mouse kidney display a larger diameter relative to wild-
CC       type (PubMed:16847696). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16025300,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16847696, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24368895}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the two pore domain potassium channel (TC
CC       1.A.1.8) family. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Ma L., Roman-Campos D., Austin E.D., Eyries M., Sampson K.S.,
RA   Soubrier F., Germain M., Tregouet D.A., Borczuk A., Rosenzweig E.B.,
RA   Girerd B., Montani D., Humbert M., Loyd J.E., Kass R.S., Chung W.K.;
RT   "A novel channelopathy in pulmonary arterial hypertension.";
RL   N. Engl. J. Med. 369:351-361(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: pH-dependent, voltage-insensitive, background potassium
CC       channel protein. Rectification direction results from potassium
CC       ion concentration on either side of the membrane. Acts as an
CC       outward rectifier when external potassium concentration is low.
CC       When external potassium concentration is high, current is inward.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23169818, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9312005}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer (Probable). Heterodimer with KCNK1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23169818, ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23169818};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Widespread expression in adult. Strongest
CC       expression in pancreas and placenta. Lower expression in brain,
CC       lung, prostate, heart, kidney, uterus, small intestine and colon.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Pulmonary hypertension, primary, 4 (PPH4) [MIM:615344]: A
CC       rare disorder characterized by plexiform lesions of proliferating
CC       endothelial cells in pulmonary arterioles. The lesions lead to
CC       elevated pulmonary arterial pression, right ventricular failure,
CC       and death. The disease can occur from infancy throughout life and
CC       it has a mean age at onset of 36 years. Penetrance is reduced.
CC       Although familial pulmonary hypertension is rare, cases secondary
CC       to known etiologies are more common and include those associated
CC       with the appetite-suppressant drugs.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23883380}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Inhibited by external acidification. Activated by
CC       halothane and isoflurane.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the two pore domain potassium channel (TC
CC       1.A.1.8) family. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   de la Cruz I.P., Ma L., Horvitz H.R.;
RT   "The Caenorhabditis elegans iodotyrosine deiodinase ortholog SUP-18

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Potassium channel involved in coordination of muscle
CC       contraction (PubMed:14534247). Activity is regulated by sup-18
CC       (PubMed:24586202). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14534247,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24586202}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: May form a complex with the regulatory subunits unc-93
CC       and sup-10. {ECO:0000303|PubMed:14534247}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000305}. Note=Associated with dense bodies.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14534247}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Low levels along surface of body-wall muscle
CC       cells, in vulval and intestinal muscles and, more weakly, in anal
CC       depressor and sphincter muscles. Also expressed in a subset of
CC       head neurons. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11301195,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14534247}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expressed in body wall muscles from 3.5-fold
CC       stage of embryogenesis with highest levels in late embryos and L1
CC       stage larvae. Lower levels persist to adulthood.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14534247}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Uncoordinated rubber band response is phenocopied
CC       by exposure to the unc-49 agonist muscimol.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14534247}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the two pore domain potassium channel (TC
CC       1.A.1.8) family. {ECO:0000255}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Potassium channel subunit that does not form functional
CC       channels by itself. Can form functional heterotetrameric channels
CC       with KCNB1 and KCNB2; modulates the delayed rectifier voltage-
CC       gated potassium channel activation and deactivation rates of KCNB1
CC       and KCNB2 (PubMed:9305895). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9305895}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer with KCNB1 and KCNB2 (PubMed:9305895).
CC       Does not form homomultimers (PubMed:9305895).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9305895}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9305895};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}. Note=May not reach the
CC       plasma membrane but remain in an intracellular compartment in the
CC       absence of KCNB1 or KCNB2 (PubMed:9305895).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9305895}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in brain, but not in the other
CC       tissues tested. The highest levels of expression are in olfactory
CC       bulb, cerebral cortex, hippocampus, habenula, basolateral
CC       amygdaloid nuclei and cerebellum (PubMed:9305895).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9305895}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The transmembrane segment S4 functions as voltage-sensor
CC       and is characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids
CC       at every third position. Channel opening and closing is effected
CC       by a conformation change that affects the position and orientation
CC       of the voltage-sensor paddle formed by S3 and S4 within the
CC       membrane. A transmembrane electric field that is positive inside
CC       would push the positively charged S4 segment outwards, thereby
CC       opening the pore, while a field that is negative inside would pull
CC       the S4 segment inwards and close the pore. Changes in the position
CC       and orientation of S4 are then transmitted to the activation gate
CC       formed by the inner helix bundle via the S4-S5 linker region.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P63142}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. S (TC
CC       1.A.1.2) subfamily. Kv9.1/KCNS1 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RP   GLN-581, AND VARIANT SER-777.
RX   PubMed=27864847; DOI=10.1002/humu.23149;
RG   Clinical Study Group;
RA   Parrini E., Marini C., Mei D., Galuppi A., Cellini E., Pucatti D.,
RA   Chiti L., Rutigliano D., Bianchini C., Virdo S., De Vita D.,
RA   Bigoni S., Barba C., Mari F., Montomoli M., Pisano T., Rosati A.,

RT   "Diagnostic targeted resequencing in 349 patients with drug-resistant
RT   pediatric epilepsies identifies causative mutations in 30 different
RT   genes.";
RL   Hum. Mutat. 38:216-225(2017).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Associates with KCNQ3 to form a potassium channel with
CC       essentially identical properties to the channel underlying the
CC       native M-current, a slowly activating and deactivating potassium
CC       conductance which plays a critical role in determining the
CC       subthreshold electrical excitability of neurons as well as the
CC       responsiveness to synaptic inputs. Therefore, it is important in
CC       the regulation of neuronal excitability. KCNQ2/KCNQ3 current is
CC       blocked by linopirdine and XE991, and activated by the
CC       anticonvulsant retigabine (PubMed:9836639, PubMed:11572947,
CC       PubMed:14534157, PubMed:12742592, PubMed:17872363). As the native
CC       M-channel, the potassium channel composed of KCNQ2 and KCNQ3 is
CC       also suppressed by activation of the muscarinic acetylcholine
CC       receptor CHRM1 (PubMed:10684873). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10684873,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11572947, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12742592,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14534157, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17872363,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9836639}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer with KCNQ3; form the heterotetrameric M
CC       potassium channel (PubMed:9836639, PubMed:27564677). Interacts
CC       with calmodulin; the interaction is calcium-independent,
CC       constitutive and participates to the proper assembly of a
CC       functional heterotetrameric M channel (PubMed:27564677). May
CC       associate with KCNE2 (PubMed:11034315). Interacts with IQCJ-SCHIP1
CC       (By similarity). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9Z351,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11034315, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27564677,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9836639}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10788442,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9836639}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=6;
CC         Comment=Additional isoforms seem to exist.;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=O43526-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=O43526-2; Sequence=VSP_000988;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=O43526-3; Sequence=VSP_000985, VSP_000988;
CC         Note=May be produced at very low levels due to a premature stop
CC         codon in the mRNA, leading to nonsense-mediated mRNA decay.;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=O43526-4; Sequence=VSP_000989, VSP_000990;
CC       Name=5;
CC         IsoId=O43526-5; Sequence=VSP_000984, VSP_000988;
CC       Name=6; Synonyms=HNSPC;
CC         IsoId=O43526-6; Sequence=VSP_000986, VSP_000987;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: In adult and fetal brain. Highly expressed in
CC       areas containing neuronal cell bodies, low in spinal chord and
CC       corpus callosum. Isoform 2 is preferentially expressed in
CC       differentiated neurons. Isoform 6 is prominent in fetal brain,
CC       undifferentiated neuroblastoma cells and brain tumors.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10781098}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and is
CC       characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids at
CC       every third position. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: KCNQ2/KCNQ3 heteromeric current can be increased by
CC       intracellular cyclic AMP, an effect that depends on
CC       phosphorylation of Ser-52 in the N-terminal region.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16319223, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9872318}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Seizures, benign familial neonatal 1 (BFNS1)
CC       [MIM:121200]: A disorder characterized by clusters of seizures
CC       occurring in the first days of life. Most patients have
CC       spontaneous remission by 12 months of age and show normal
CC       psychomotor development. Some rare cases manifest an atypical
CC       severe phenotype associated with epileptic encephalopathy and
CC       psychomotor retardation. The disorder is distinguished from benign
CC       familial infantile seizures by an earlier age at onset. In some
CC       patients, neonatal convulsions are followed later in life by
CC       myokymia, a benign condition characterized by spontaneous
CC       involuntary contractions of skeletal muscles fiber groups that can
CC       be observed as vermiform movement of the overlying skin.
CC       Electromyography typically shows continuous motor unit activity
CC       with spontaneous oligo- and multiplet-discharges of high
CC       intraburst frequency (myokymic discharges). Some patients may have
CC       isolated myokymia. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11175290,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11572947, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14534157,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15249611, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23360469,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25982755, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26993267,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9425895}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Epileptic encephalopathy, early infantile, 7 (EIEE7)
CC       [MIM:613720]: An autosomal dominant seizure disorder characterized
CC       by infantile onset of refractory seizures with resultant delayed
CC       neurologic development and persistent neurologic abnormalities.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12742592, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15249611,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24463883, ECO:0000269|PubMed:25818041,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26138355, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26993267,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27864847}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Inclusion of isoform 6 in heteromultimers results
CC       in attenuation of potassium current. Prominent expression of
CC       isoform 6 in the developing brain may alter firing repertoires of
CC       immature neurons excitability to provide cues for proliferation
CC       rather than differentiation.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. KQT (TC
CC       1.A.1.15) subfamily. Kv7.2/KCNQ2 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Pore-forming (alpha) subunit of voltage-gated potassium
CC       channel. Channel properties may be modulated by cAMP and subunit
CC       assembly.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The potassium channel is probably composed of a homo- or
CC       heterotetrameric complex of pore-forming alpha subunits that can
CC       associate with modulating beta subunits. Heteromultimer with
CC       KCNH2/ERG1 and KCNH6/ERG2.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in total brain, in superior cervical,
CC       mesenteric and celiac ganglia, and at very low levels in retina.
CC       Found in pituitary. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10718922}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and is
CC       characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids at
CC       every third position.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. H (Eag) (TC
CC       1.A.1.20) subfamily. Kv11.3/KCNH7 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Dixon J.E.;
RT   "Identification of two nervous system-specific members of the erg
RT   potassium channel gene family.";
RL   J. Neurosci. 17:9423-9432(1997).
RN   [2]
RP   TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=10718922; DOI=10.1046/j.1365-2826.2000.00447.x;
RA   Wulfsen I., Hauber H.-P., Schiemann D., Bauer C.K., Schwarz J.R.;
RT   "Expression of mRNA for voltage-dependent and inward-rectifying K
RT   channels in GH3/B6 cells and rat pituitary.";
RL   J. Neuroendocrinol. 12:263-272(2000).
RN   [3]
RP   INTERACTION WITH KCNH2 AND KCNH7, AND MUTAGENESIS OF GLY-480.
RX   PubMed=11212207; DOI=10.1007/s004240000467;
RA   Wimmers S., Wulfsen I., Bauer C.K., Schwarz J.R.;
RT   "Erg1, erg2 and erg3 K channel subunits are able to form
RT   heteromultimers.";
RL   Pflugers Arch. 441:450-455(2001).
RN   [4]
RP   TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=11425889;
RA   Saganich M.J., Machado E., Rudy B.;
RT   "Differential expression of genes encoding subthreshold-operating
RT   voltage-gated K+ channels in brain.";
RL   J. Neurosci. 21:4609-4624(2001).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Pore-forming (alpha) subunit of voltage-gated potassium
CC       channel. Elicits a slowly activating, rectifying current. Channel
CC       properties may be modulated by cAMP and subunit assembly.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The potassium channel is probably composed of a homo- or
CC       heterotetrameric complex of pore-forming alpha subunits that can
CC       associate with modulating beta subunits. Heteromultimer with
CC       KCNH2/ERG1 and KCNH7/ERG3.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Highly expressed in celiac and superior
CC       mesenteric ganglia, but not detected in brain or in heart.
CC       Detected at low levels in retina. Also found in pituitary. Also
CC       found in the olfactory bulb (granular and mitral cell layers)
CC       (PubMed:11425889). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10718922,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11425889}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and is
CC       characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids at
CC       every third position.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. H (Eag) (TC
CC       1.A.1.20) subfamily. Kv11.2/KCNH6 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
