ID   KCNA6_HUMAN             Reviewed;         529 AA.
AC   P17658;
DT   01-AUG-1990, integrated into UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot.
DT   01-AUG-1990, sequence version 1.
DT   22-NOV-2017, entry version 163.
DE   RecName: Full=Potassium voltage-gated channel subfamily A member 6;
DE   AltName: Full=Voltage-gated potassium channel HBK2 {ECO:0000303|PubMed:2347305};
DE   AltName: Full=Voltage-gated potassium channel subunit Kv1.6;
GN   Name=KCNA6;
OS   Homo sapiens (Human).
OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Chordata; Craniata; Vertebrata; Euteleostomi;
OC   Mammalia; Eutheria; Euarchontoglires; Primates; Haplorrhini;
OC   Catarrhini; Hominidae; Homo.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=9606;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA], FUNCTION, AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RC   TISSUE=Brain;
RX   PubMed=2347305;
RA   Grupe A., Schroeter K.H., Ruppersberg J.P., Stocker M., Drewes T.,
RA   Beckh S., Pongs O.;
RT   "Cloning and expression of a human voltage-gated potassium channel. A
RT   novel member of the RCK potassium channel family.";
RL   EMBO J. 9:1749-1756(1990).
RN   [2]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA].
RX   PubMed=15489334; DOI=10.1101/gr.2596504;
RG   The MGC Project Team;
RT   "The status, quality, and expansion of the NIH full-length cDNA
RT   project: the Mammalian Gene Collection (MGC).";
RL   Genome Res. 14:2121-2127(2004).
RN   [3]
RP   FUNCTION, AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=14575698; DOI=10.1016/j.bbrc.2003.09.167;
RA   Guihard G., Bellocq C., Grelet E., Escande D.;
RT   "Human Kv1.6 current displays a C-type-like inactivation when re-
RT   expressed in cos-7 cells.";
RL   Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 311:83-89(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-gated potassium channel that mediates
CC       transmembrane potassium transport in excitable membranes. Forms
CC       tetrameric potassium-selective channels through which potassium
CC       ions pass in accordance with their electrochemical gradient
CC       (PubMed:2347305, PubMed:14575698). The channel alternates between
CC       opened and closed conformations in response to the voltage
CC       difference across the membrane (PubMed:2347305, PubMed:14575698).
CC       Can form functional homotetrameric channels and heterotetrameric
CC       channels that contain variable proportions of KCNA1, KCNA2, KCNA4,
CC       KCNA6, and possibly other family members as well; channel
CC       properties depend on the type of alpha subunits that are part of
CC       the channel (By similarity). Channel properties are modulated by
CC       cytoplasmic beta subunits that regulate the subcellular location
CC       of the alpha subunits and promote rapid inactivation (By
CC       similarity). Homotetrameric channels display rapid activation and
CC       slow inactivation (PubMed:2347305). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P17659,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14575698, ECO:0000269|PubMed:2347305}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer and heterotetramer of potassium channel
CC       proteins (By similarity). Interacts with KCNAB1 and KCNAB2 (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P17659, ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14575698,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2347305}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The N-terminus may be important in determining the rate of
CC       inactivation of the channel while the tail may play a role in
CC       modulation of channel activity and/or targeting of the channel to
CC       specific subcellular compartments.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The transmembrane segment S4 functions as voltage-sensor
CC       and is characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids
CC       at every third position. Channel opening and closing is effected
CC       by a conformation change that affects the position and orientation
CC       of the voltage-sensor paddle formed by S3 and S4 within the
CC       membrane. A transmembrane electric field that is positive inside
CC       would push the positively charged S4 segment outwards, thereby
CC       opening the pore, while a field that is negative inside would pull
CC       the S4 segment inwards and close the pore. Changes in the position
CC       and orientation of S4 are then transmitted to the activation gate
CC       formed by the inner helix bundle via the S4-S5 linker region.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P63142}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. A (Shaker)
CC       (TC 1.A.1.2) subfamily. Kv1.6/KCNA6 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RX   PubMed=12537572; DOI=10.1186/gb-2002-3-12-research0083;
RA   Misra S., Crosby M.A., Mungall C.J., Matthews B.B., Campbell K.S.,
RA   Hradecky P., Huang Y., Kaminker J.S., Millburn G.H., Prochnik S.E.,
RA   Smith C.D., Tupy J.L., Whitfield E.J., Bayraktaroglu L., Berman B.P.,

RT   systematic review.";
RL   Genome Biol. 3:RESEARCH0083.1-RESEARCH0083.22(2002).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Mediates the voltage-dependent potassium ion
CC       permeability of excitable membranes. Assuming opened or closed
CC       conformations in response to the voltage difference across the
CC       membrane, the protein forms a potassium-selective channel through
CC       which potassium ions may pass in accordance with their
CC       electrochemical gradient.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer of potassium channel proteins.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=B;
CC         IsoId=P17970-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=A;
CC         IsoId=P17970-2; Sequence=VSP_000960;
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expressed in late embryos and pupae.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The N-terminus may be important in determining the rate of
CC       inactivation of the channel while the tail may play a role in
CC       modulation of channel activity and/or targeting of the channel to
CC       specific subcellular compartments.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and
CC       is characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids at
CC       every third position.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. B (Shab) (TC
CC       1.A.1.2) subfamily. Shab sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAG22232.2; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally shortened.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=AAG22233.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally shortened.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Mediates the voltage-dependent potassium ion
CC       permeability of excitable membranes. Assuming opened or closed
CC       conformations in response to the voltage difference across the
CC       membrane, the protein forms a potassium-selective channel through
CC       which potassium ions may pass in accordance with their
CC       electrochemical gradient.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer of potassium channel proteins.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and
CC       is characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids at
CC       every third position.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: This channel protein belongs to the delayed
CC       rectifier class.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. C (Shaw) (TC
CC       1.A.1.2) subfamily. Shaw sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RC   TISSUE=Lymphocyte;

RA   Cai Y.-C., Osborne P.B., North R.A., Dooley D.C., Douglass J.;

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Mediates the voltage-dependent potassium ion
CC       permeability of excitable membranes. Assuming opened or closed
CC       conformations in response to the voltage difference across the
CC       membrane, the protein forms a potassium-selective channel through
CC       which potassium ions may pass in accordance with their
CC       electrochemical gradient.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer of potassium channel proteins. Binds PDZ
CC       domains of DLG1, DLG2 and DLG4 (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q07812:BAX; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8627664, EBI-516580;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000250}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The N-terminus may be important in determining the rate of
CC       inactivation of the channel while the tail may play a role in
CC       modulation of channel activity and/or targeting of the channel to
CC       specific subcellular compartments.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and is
CC       characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids at
CC       every third position.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylation promotes the cell surface expression.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. A (Shaker)
CC       (TC 1.A.1.2) subfamily. Kv1.3/KCNA3 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: It is uncertain whether Met-1 or Met-53 is the initiator.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAA36425.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally extended.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=AAA36425.1; Type=Frameshift; Positions=42; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=AAA59457.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally extended.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=AAA59457.1; Type=Frameshift; Positions=Several; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=AAB88073.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=AAC31761.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally extended.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=AAC31761.1; Type=Frameshift; Positions=Several; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RN   [18]
RP   FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=22831914; DOI=10.1016/j.ceca.2012.06.007;
RA   Kuznetsov K.I., Grygorov O.O., Maslov V.Y., Veselovsky N.S.,
RA   Fedulova S.A.;
RT   "Kv3 channels modulate calcium signals induced by fast firing patterns
RT   in the rat retinal ganglion cells.";
RL   Cell Calcium 52:405-411(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-gated potassium channel that mediates
CC       transmembrane potassium transport in excitable membranes,
CC       primarily in the brain. Contributes to the regulation of the fast
CC       action potential repolarization and in sustained high-frequency
CC       firing in neurons of the central nervous system (PubMed:10482766,
CC       PubMed:10414968, PubMed:11506885, PubMed:22831914). Homotetramer
CC       channels mediate delayed-rectifier voltage-dependent potassium
CC       currents that activate rapidly at high-threshold voltages and
CC       inactivate slowly (PubMed:2367536, PubMed:1879548, PubMed:8120636,
CC       PubMed:7643197, PubMed:10414303). Forms tetrameric channels
CC       through which potassium ions pass in accordance with their
CC       electrochemical gradient. The channel alternates between opened
CC       and closed conformations in response to the voltage difference
CC       across the membrane (PubMed:2367536, PubMed:1879548,
CC       PubMed:8120636, PubMed:7643197). Can form functional
CC       homotetrameric channels and heterotetrameric channels that contain
CC       variable proportions of KCNC1, and possibly other family members
CC       as well; channel properties depend on the type of alpha subunits
CC       that are part of the channel (PubMed:10482766, PubMed:14679187).
CC       Channel properties may be modulated either by the association with
CC       ancillary subunits, such as KCNE1, KCNE2 and KCNE3 or indirectly
CC       by nitric oxide (NO) through a cGMP- and PKG-mediated signaling
CC       cascade, slowing channel activation and deactivation of delayed
CC       rectifier potassium channels (PubMed:11281123, PubMed:14679187).
CC       Contributes to fire sustained trains of very brief action
CC       potentials at high frequency in retinal ganglion cells,
CC       thalamocortical and suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) neurons and in
CC       hippocampal and neocortical interneurons (PubMed:10482766,
CC       PubMed:10414968, PubMed:11506885, PubMed:22831914). Sustained
CC       maximal action potential firing frequency in inhibitory
CC       hippocampal interneurons is negatively modulated by histamine H2
CC       receptor activation in a cAMP- and protein kinase (PKA)
CC       phosphorylation-dependent manner. Plays a role in maintaining the
CC       fidelity of synaptic transmission in neocortical GABAergic
CC       interneurons by generating action potential (AP) repolarization at
CC       nerve terminals, thus reducing spike-evoked calcium influx and
CC       GABA neurotransmitter release. Required for long-range
CC       synchronization of gamma oscillations over distance in the
CC       neocortex. Contributes to the modulation of the circadian rhythm
CC       of spontaneous action potential firing in suprachiasmatic nucleus
CC       (SCN) neurons in a light-dependent manner (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q14B80, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10414968,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10482766, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11281123,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11506885, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14679187,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:1879548, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22831914,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2367536, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7643197,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8120636, ECO:0000305|PubMed:10414303,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:11506885}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by Stichodactyla helianthus peptide
CC       ShK (By similarity). Inhibited by millimolar levels of
CC       tetraethylammonium (TEA). Contrary to other channels, inhibited
CC       only by millimolar levels of 4-aminopyridine (4-AP)
CC       (PubMed:2367536, PubMed:1879548, PubMed:7643197, PubMed:10482766,
CC       PubMed:10414303). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q96PR1,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10482766, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1879548,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2367536, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7643197,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:10414303}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         Note=Homotetrameric channels expressed in xenopus oocytes or in
CC         mammalian non-neuronal cells display delayed-rectifier voltage-
CC         dependent potassium currents, that are rapidly activated during
CC         membrane depolarization, i.e within a risetime of a few msec.
CC         After that, inactivates very slowly, i.e within about >800 msec.
CC         Their activation requires a threshold potential at about -10 mV,
CC         with a midpoint activation at about 12.1 mV and a steepness
CC         parameter of about 8.4 mV (PubMed:2367536, PubMed:1879548,
CC         PubMed:8120636, PubMed:7643197, PubMed:10414303,
CC         PubMed:11281123, PubMed:14679187). The voltage-dependence of
CC         activation and inactivation and other channel characteristics
CC         vary depending on the experimental conditions, the expression
CC         system, the presence or absence of ancillary subunits and post-
CC         translational modifications (PubMed:7643197, PubMed:10414303,
CC         PubMed:11281123, PubMed:14679187). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11281123,
CC         ECO:0000269|PubMed:14679187, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1879548,
CC         ECO:0000269|PubMed:2367536, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7643197,
CC         ECO:0000269|PubMed:8120636, ECO:0000305|PubMed:10414303};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer and heterotetramer with other channel-
CC       forming alpha subunits, such as KCNC1. Interacts with KCNC1
CC       (PubMed:10482766, PubMed:14679187). Homotetramer or heterotetramer
CC       channel activity is regulated by association with modulating
CC       ancillary subunits such as KCNE1, KCNE2 and KCNE3, creating a
CC       functionally diverse range of channel complexes. Interacts with
CC       KCNE1, KCNE2 and KCNE3 (PubMed:14679187).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10482766, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14679187}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10414968,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10482766, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14679187,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:1879548, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22831914,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2367536, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7643197,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8120636}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255}. Membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11281123}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000255}. Perikaryon
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10482766}. Cell projection, axon
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7643197}. Cell junction, synapse
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7643197}. Cell junction, synapse, synaptosome
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7643197}. Cell projection, dendrite
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q14B80}. Cell junction, synapse,
CC       postsynaptic cell membrane {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q14B80}. Cell
CC       junction, synapse, presynaptic cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q14B80}. Note=Localizes on the surface of
CC       cell somata, proximal dendrites and axonal membranes. Also
CC       detected throughout the neuropil. Localized in starburst cell
CC       somata and proximal dendrite processes. Colocalized with GABA in
CC       presynaptic terminals. Clustered in patches in somatic and
CC       proximal dendritic membrane as well as in axons and presnypatic
CC       terminals of GABAergic interneurons; some of these patches are
CC       found near postsynaptic sites (By similarity). Colocalizes with
CC       parvalbumin in globus pallidus neurons (PubMed:10482766).
CC       Localizes in thalamocortical axons and synapses (PubMed:7643197).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q14B80, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10482766,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7643197}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 1: Apical cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9307441}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 2: Apical cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9307441}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 3: Basolateral cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9307441}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=4;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=KV3.2B {ECO:0000303|PubMed:1879548};
CC         IsoId=P22462-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=KV3.2C {ECO:0000303|PubMed:1879548};
CC         IsoId=P22462-2; Sequence=VSP_001018;
CC       Name=3; Synonyms=KV3.2A, KShIIIA.1 {ECO:0000303|PubMed:2367536};
CC         IsoId=P22462-3; Sequence=VSP_001019;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=P22462-4; Sequence=VSP_001020;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in neurons of the visual cortex
CC       during postnatal development (PubMed:18708127). Expressed in
CC       neurons of the globus pallidus at postnatal age day 7 (P7), onward
CC       (PubMed:10482766). Expressed in thalamic relay neurons. Expressed
CC       in neurons in layer IV and deeper cortical layers of the
CC       neocortex. Expressed in hippocampal interneurons (PubMed:7643197).
CC       Expressed in nonpyramidal interneurons in the basolateral amygdala
CC       (PubMed:16413129). Expressed in retinal ganglion cells (at protein
CC       level) (PubMed:22831914). Widely expressed in the brain
CC       (PubMed:1879548, PubMed:8120636). Expressed in numerous thalamic
CC       relay neurons throughout the dorsal thalamus. Expressed in
CC       interneurons of the deep layers V-VI of the cerebral cortex, the
CC       CA1 and CA3 pyramidal and dentate gyrus (DG) granule cells of the
CC       hippocampus, in neurons of the caudate-putamen, globus pallidus
CC       and subthalamic nucleus. Also expressed in the optic layer of
CC       interior colliculus, the inferior colliculus, the red nucleus, the
CC       medial geniculate, the ventral lateral lemiscus, the
CC       reticulotegmental nucleus and in the deep cerebellar nuclei
CC       (PubMed:1374908, PubMed:8120636, PubMed:7643197, PubMed:18708127).
CC       Expressed in globus pallidus (GP) neurons (PubMed:10414968).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10414968, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10482766,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:1374908, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16413129,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18708127, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1879548,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22831914, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7643197,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8120636}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Up-regulated in visual cortex during the second
CC       postnatal week from dark-reared animals (at protein level). Down-
CC       regulated in visual cortex by active visual experience until
CC       postnatal day P40 of dark-reared animals (PubMed:18708127). Down-
CC       regulated by chronic action potential activity deprivation in
CC       organotypic culture of the visual cortex (PubMed:18775767).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18708127, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18775767}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The transmembrane segment S4 functions as voltage-sensor
CC       and is characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids
CC       at every third position. Channel opening and closing is effected
CC       by a conformation change that affects the position and orientation
CC       of the voltage-sensor paddle formed by S3 and S4 within the
CC       membrane. A transmembrane electric field that is positive inside
CC       would push the positively charged S4 segment outwards, thereby
CC       opening the pore, while a field that is negative inside would pull
CC       the S4 segment inwards and close the pore. Changes in the position
CC       and orientation of S4 are then transmitted to the activation gate
CC       formed by the inner helix bundle via the S4-S5 linker region.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P63142}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated by PKA in cortical synaptosomes
CC       (PubMed:7643197). cAMP-dependent phosphorylation inhibits channel
CC       activity (PubMed:7643197). Histamine H2 receptor- and PKA-induced
CC       phosphorylation extends action potential spike duration, reduces
CC       action potential spike amplitude, sustains maximum firing
CC       frequency in hippocampal interneurons; also reduces the incidence
CC       of high-frequency oscillations in hippocampal CA3 pyramidal cell
CC       layers (By similarity). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P63142,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7643197}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. C (Shaw) (TC
CC       1.A.1.2) subfamily. Kv3.2/KCNC2 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-gated potassium channel that plays an important
CC       role in the rapid repolarization of fast-firing brain neurons. The
CC       channel opens in response to the voltage difference across the
CC       membrane, forming a potassium-selective channel through which
CC       potassium ions pass in accordance with their electrochemical
CC       gradient (PubMed:25401298). Can form functional homotetrameric
CC       channels and heterotetrameric channels that contain variable
CC       proportions of KCNC2, and possibly other family members as well.
CC       Contributes to fire sustained trains of very brief action
CC       potentials at high frequency in pallidal neurons.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P25122, ECO:0000269|PubMed:25401298}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heteromultimer with KCNG3, KCNG4 and KCNV2 (By
CC       similarity). Heteromultimer with KCNC2 (By similarity).
CC       Heterotetramer with KCNC3 (PubMed:23734863). Interacts with the
CC       ancillary subunits KCNE1 and KCNE2; the interaction modulates
CC       channel activity (By similarity). {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P25122, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23734863}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25401298};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=P48547-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=P48547-2; Sequence=VSP_055129;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available. Gene prediction
CC         based on EST data.;
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and is
CC       characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids at
CC       every third position. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The tail may be important in modulation of channel
CC       activity and/or targeting of the channel to specific subcellular
CC       compartments. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylated; contains sialylated glycans.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P25122}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Epilepsy, progressive myoclonic 7 (EPM7) [MIM:616187]: A
CC       neurologic disorder characterized by progressive myoclonic
CC       epilepsy, manifesting in the first or second decades of life.
CC       Cognitive function may decline in some patients. Myoclonus is a
CC       brief, involuntary twitching of a muscle or a group of muscles.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25401298}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. C (Shaw) (TC
CC       1.A.1.2) subfamily. Kv3.1/KCNC1 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   VARIANT LQT1 THR-590, AND CHARACTERIZATION OF VARIANT LQT1 THR-590.

RN   [71]
RP   CHARACTERIZATION OF VARIANTS LQT1 ASN-242; PRO-243; HIS-250; VAL-306;
RP   ASN-317; ASP-586 AND MET-619, AND CHARACTERIZATION OF VARIANTS JLNS1
RP   PHE-248; ILE-311; MET-322 AND ASP-589.
RX   PubMed=25705178; DOI=10.3389/fncel.2015.00032;
RA   Mousavi Nik A., Gharaie S., Jeong Kim H.;
RT   "Cellular mechanisms of mutations in Kv7.1: auditory functions in
RT   Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome vs. Romano-Ward syndrome.";
RL   Front. Cell. Neurosci. 9:32-32(2015).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Potassium channel that plays an important role in a
CC       number of tissues, including heart, inner ear, stomach and colon
CC       (By similarity) (PubMed:10646604). Associates with KCNE beta
CC       subunits that modulates current kinetics (By similarity)
CC       (PubMed:9312006, PubMed:9108097, PubMed:8900283, PubMed:10646604,
CC       PubMed:11101505, PubMed:19687231). Induces a voltage-dependent by
CC       rapidly activating and slowly deactivating potassium-selective
CC       outward current (By similarity) (PubMed:9312006, PubMed:9108097,
CC       PubMed:8900283, PubMed:10646604, PubMed:11101505). Promotes also a
CC       delayed voltage activated potassium current showing outward
CC       rectification characteristic (By similarity). During beta-
CC       adrenergic receptor stimulation participates in cardiac
CC       repolarization by associating with KCNE1 to form the I(Ks) cardiac
CC       potassium current that increases the amplitude and slows down the
CC       activation kinetics of outward potassium current I(Ks) (By
CC       similarity) (PubMed:9312006, PubMed:9108097, PubMed:8900283,
CC       PubMed:10646604, PubMed:11101505). Muscarinic agonist
CC       oxotremorine-M strongly suppresses KCNQ1/KCNE1 current
CC       (PubMed:10713961). When associated with KCNE3, forms the potassium
CC       channel that is important for cyclic AMP-stimulated intestinal
CC       secretion of chloride ions (PubMed:10646604). This interaction
CC       with KCNE3 is reduced by 17beta-estradiol, resulting in the
CC       reduction of currents (By similarity). During conditions of
CC       increased substrate load, maintains the driving force for proximal
CC       tubular and intestinal sodium ions absorption, gastric acid
CC       secretion, and cAMP-induced jejunal chloride ions secretion (By
CC       similarity). Allows the provision of potassium ions to the luminal
CC       membrane of the secretory canaliculus in the resting state as well
CC       as during stimulated acid secretion (By similarity). When
CC       associated with KCNE2, forms a heterooligomer complex leading to
CC       currents with an apparently instantaneous activation, a rapid
CC       deactivation process and a linear current-voltage relationship and
CC       decreases the amplitude of the outward current (PubMed:11101505).
CC       When associated with KCNE4, inhibits voltage-gated potassium
CC       channel activity (PubMed:19687231). When associated with KCNE5,
CC       this complex only conducts current upon strong and continued
CC       depolarization (PubMed:12324418). Also forms a heterotetramer with
CC       KCNQ5; has a voltage-gated potassium channel activity
CC       (PubMed:24855057). Binds with phosphatidylinositol 4,5-
CC       bisphosphate (PubMed:25037568). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P97414,
CC       ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9Z0N7, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10646604,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10713961, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11101505,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12324418, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19687231,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24855057, ECO:0000269|PubMed:25037568,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8900283, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9108097,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9312006}.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Isoform 2: Non-functional alone but modulatory when
CC       coexpressed with the full-length isoform 1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9305853}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Tetramer (PubMed:18165683, PubMed:19693805).
CC       Heterotetramer with KCNE1; targets to the membrane raft
CC       (PubMed:25037568, PubMed:19693805, PubMed:20533308). Interacts
CC       (via C-terminus) with CALM; forms a heterotetramer in a calcium-
CC       independent manner (PubMed:18165683). Interacts with AKAP9;
CC       targets protein kinase A (PKA) catalytic and regulatory subunits
CC       and protein phosphatase 1 (PP1) to the KCNQ1-KCNE1 complex,
CC       allowing PKA-mediated phosphorylation and increase of delayed
CC       rectifier potassium channel activity (PubMed:11799244,
CC       PubMed:25037568). Interacts with KCNE2; forms a heterooligomer
CC       complex that targets to the membrane raft and leading to currents
CC       with an apparently instantaneous activation, a rapid deactivation
CC       process and a linear current-voltage relationship and decreases
CC       the amplitude of the outward current (PubMed:11101505,
CC       PubMed:20533308). Interacts with AP2M1; mediates estrogen-induced
CC       internalization via clathrin-coated vesicles (PubMed:23529131).
CC       Interacts with NEDD4L; promotes internalization and decreases
CC       I(Ks) currents (PubMed:23529131, PubMed:22024150). Interacts with
CC       USP2; counteracts the NEDD4L-specific down-regulation of I(Ks) and
CC       restore plasma membrane localization (PubMed:22024150).
CC       Heterotetramer with KCNQ5; has a voltage-gated potassium channel
CC       activity (PubMed:24855057). Interacts with KCNE3; alters membrane
CC       raft localization (PubMed:20533308). Interacts with KCNE4; impairs
CC       KCNQ1 localization in lipid rafts and inhibits voltage-gated
CC       potassium channel activity (PubMed:19687231, PubMed:20533308).
CC       Interacts with KCNE5; impairs KCNQ1 localization in lipid rafts
CC       and only conducts current upon strong and continued depolarization
CC       (PubMed:20533308, PubMed:12324418). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11101505,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11799244, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12324418,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18165683, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19687231,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19693805, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20533308,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22024150, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23529131,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24855057, ECO:0000269|PubMed:25037568}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P62158:CALM3; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-15885881, EBI-397435;
CC       P15382:KCNE1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-359667, EBI-7043557;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10646604,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18165683, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21228319,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22024150, ECO:0000269|PubMed:25037568}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18165683}. Cytoplasmic
CC       vesicle membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18165683,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23529131}. Early endosome
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23529131}. Membrane raft
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20533308, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24855057}.
CC       Endoplasmic reticulum {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21228319,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24855057}. Basolateral cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21228319}. Note=Colocalized with KCNE3 at the
CC       plasma membrane (PubMed:10646604). Upon 17beta-oestradiol
CC       treatment, colocalizes with RAB5A at early endosome
CC       (PubMed:23529131). Heterotetramer with KCNQ5 is highly retained at
CC       the endoplasmic reticulum and is localized outside of lipid raft
CC       microdomains (PubMed:24855057). During the early stages of
CC       epithelial cell polarization induced by the calcium switch it
CC       removed from plasma membrane to the endoplasmic reticulum where it
CC       retained and it is redistributed to the basolateral cell surface
CC       in a PI3K-dependent manner at a later stage (PubMed:21228319).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10646604, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21228319,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23529131, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24855057}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC         Comment=Additional isoforms seem to exist.;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=P51787-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=TKvLQT1;
CC         IsoId=P51787-2; Sequence=VSP_000981, VSP_000982;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Abundantly expressed in heart, pancreas,
CC       prostate, kidney, small intestine and peripheral blood leukocytes.
CC       Less abundant in placenta, lung, spleen, colon, thymus, testis and
CC       ovaries.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and is
CC       characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids at
CC       every third position.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The coiled-coil domain mediates tetramerization.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18165683, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19693805}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S6 is involved in the inhibition of voltage-
CC       gated potassium channel activity by KCNE4.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19687231}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The C-terminal assembly domain promotes self-interactiona;
CC       allows functional channel. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10654932}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation at Ser-27 by PKA; increases delayed rectifier
CC       potassium channel activity of the KCNQ1-KCNE1 complex through a
CC       macromolecular complex that includes PKA, PP1, and the targeting
CC       protein AKAP9. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11799244,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25037568}.
CC   -!- PTM: Ubiquitinated by NEDD4L; promotes internalization
CC       (PubMed:22024150). The ubiquitinylated form is internalized
CC       through a clathrin-mediated endocytosis by interacting with AP2M1
CC       and is recycled back to the cell membrane via RAB4A and RAB11A
CC       (PubMed:23529131). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22024150,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23529131}.
CC   -!- PTM: Deubiquitinated by USP2; counteracts the NEDD4L-specific
CC       down-regulation of I(Ks) and restores the membrane localization.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22024150}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Long QT syndrome 1 (LQT1) [MIM:192500]: A heart disorder
CC       characterized by a prolonged QT interval on the ECG and
CC       polymorphic ventricular arrhythmias. They cause syncope and sudden
CC       death in response to exercise or emotional stress, and can present
CC       with a sentinel event of sudden cardiac death in infancy.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10024302, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10220144,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10220146, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10367071,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10409658, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10482963,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10728423, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10973849,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11799244, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12442276,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15840476, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16414944,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16922724, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18165683,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18400097, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19540844,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19716085, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21241800,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24184248, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24269949,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24713462, ECO:0000269|PubMed:25037568,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25139741, ECO:0000269|PubMed:25705178,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8528244, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8818942,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8872472, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9024139,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9272155, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9302275,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9312006, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9323054,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9386136, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9482580,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9570196, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9641694,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9693036, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9702906,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9799083, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9927399,
CC       ECO:0000269|Ref.31}. Note=The disease is caused by mutations
CC       affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome 1 (JLNS1)
CC       [MIM:220400]: An autosomal recessive disorder characterized by
CC       congenital deafness, prolongation of the QT interval, syncopal
CC       attacks due to ventricular arrhythmias, and a high risk of sudden
CC       death. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10090886, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10728423,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18400097, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18441444,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25705178, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9781056}. Note=The
CC       disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in
CC       this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Atrial fibrillation, familial, 3 (ATFB3) [MIM:607554]: An
CC       autosomal dominant form of atrial fibrillation, a common sustained
CC       cardiac rhythm disturbance. Atrial fibrillation is characterized
CC       by disorganized atrial electrical activity and ineffective atrial
CC       contraction promoting blood stasis in the atria and reduces
CC       ventricular filling. It can result in palpitations, syncope,
CC       thromboembolic stroke, and congestive heart failure.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12522251}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Short QT syndrome 2 (SQT2) [MIM:609621]: A heart disorder
CC       characterized by idiopathic persistently and uniformly short QT
CC       interval on ECG in the absence of structural heart disease in
CC       affected individuals. It causes syncope and sudden death.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15159330}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Diabetes mellitus, non-insulin-dependent (NIDDM)
CC       [MIM:125853]: A multifactorial disorder of glucose homeostasis
CC       caused by a lack of sensitivity to the body's own insulin.
CC       Affected individuals usually have an obese body habitus and
CC       manifestations of a metabolic syndrome characterized by diabetes,
CC       insulin resistance, hypertension and hypertriglyceridemia. The
CC       disease results in long-term complications that affect the eyes,
CC       kidneys, nerves, and blood vessels. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18711366,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18711367, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24390345}.
CC       Note=Disease susceptibility is associated with variations
CC       affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Mutagenesis experiments were carried out by
CC       expressing in Xenopus oocytes or COS-7 cells KCNQ1 mutants either
CC       individually (homomultimers) or in combination with both wild-type
CC       KCNQ1 (mut/wt homomultimers) and minK (heteromultimers).
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. KQT (TC
CC       1.A.1.15) subfamily. Kv7.1/KCNQ1 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Outward rectifying potassium channel. Produces rapidly
CC       activating and non-inactivating outward rectifier K(+) currents.
CC       Activated by arachidonic acid and other naturally occurring
CC       unsaturated free fatty acids.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=3;
CC       Name=A; Synonyms=TREK-2a;
CC         IsoId=P57789-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=B; Synonyms=TREK-2b;
CC         IsoId=P57789-4; Sequence=VSP_006697;
CC       Name=C; Synonyms=TREK-2c;
CC         IsoId=P57789-3; Sequence=VSP_006698;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Abundantly expressed in pancreas and kidney
CC       and to a lower level in brain, testis, colon, and small intestine.
CC       Isoform b is strongly expressed in kidney (primarily in the
CC       proximal tubule) and pancreas, whereas isoform c is abundantly
CC       expressed in brain.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the two pore domain potassium channel (TC
CC       1.A.1.8) family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT SER-406 AND SER-408, AND
RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   TISSUE=Heart, Kidney, and Pancreas;
RX   PubMed=21183079; DOI=10.1016/j.cell.2010.12.001;
RA   Huttlin E.L., Jedrychowski M.P., Elias J.E., Goswami T., Rad R.,
RA   Beausoleil S.A., Villen J., Haas W., Sowa M.E., Gygi S.P.;
RT   "A tissue-specific atlas of mouse protein phosphorylation and
RT   expression.";
RL   Cell 143:1174-1189(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Potassium channel that plays an important role in a
CC       number of tissues, including heart, inner ear, stomach and colon
CC       (By similarity) (PubMed:16314573, PubMed:11120752,
CC       PubMed:15004216). Associates with KCNE beta subunits that
CC       modulates current kinetics (By similarity) (PubMed:17597584,
CC       PubMed:15004216). Induces a voltage-dependent by rapidly
CC       activating and slowly deactivating potassium-selective outward
CC       current (By similarity) (PubMed:8900282). Promotes also a delayed
CC       voltage activated potassium current showing outward rectification
CC       characteristic (By similarity). During beta-adrenergic receptor
CC       stimulation participates in cardiac repolarization by associating
CC       with KCNE1 to form the I(Ks) cardiac potassium current that
CC       increases the amplitude and slows down the activation kinetics of
CC       outward potassium current I(Ks) (By similarity) (PubMed:15004216,
CC       PubMed:17597584). Muscarinic agonist oxotremorine-M strongly
CC       suppresses KCNQ1/KCNE1 current (By similarity). When associated
CC       with KCNE3, forms the potassium channel that is important for
CC       cyclic AMP-stimulated intestinal secretion of chloride ions (By
CC       similarity). This interaction with KCNE3 is reduced by 17beta-
CC       estradiol, resulting in the reduction of currents (By similarity).
CC       During conditions of increased substrate load, maintains the
CC       driving force for proximal tubular and intestinal sodium ions
CC       absorption, gastric acid secretion, and cAMP-induced jejunal
CC       chloride ions secretion (PubMed:16314573). Allows the provision of
CC       potassium ions to the luminal membrane of the secretory
CC       canaliculus in the resting state as well as during stimulated acid
CC       secretion (PubMed:19491250). When associated with KCNE2, forms an
CC       heterooligomer complex leading to currents with an apparently
CC       instantaneous activation, a rapid deactivation process and a
CC       linear current-voltage relationship and decreases the amplitude of
CC       the outward current (By similarity). When associated with KCNE4,
CC       inhibits voltage-gated potassium channel activity (By similarity).
CC       When associated with KCNE5, this complex only conducts current
CC       upon strong and continued depolarization (By similarity). Also
CC       forms a heterotetramer with KCNQ5; has a voltage-gated potassium
CC       channel activity (By similarity). Binds with phosphatidylinositol
CC       4,5-bisphosphate (By similarity). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P51787,
CC       ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9Z0N7, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11120752,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15004216, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16314573,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17597584, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19491250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8900282}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Tetramer (By similarity). Heterotetramer with KCNE1; form
CC       the native cardiac channel I(Ks) which increases the amplitude and
CC       slows down the activation kinetics of outward potassium current
CC       and targets to the membrane raft (By similarity) (PubMed:8900282).
CC       Interacts (via C-terminus) with CALM; forms a heterotetramer in a
CC       calcium-independent manner. Interacts with AKAP9; targets protein
CC       kinase A (PKA) catalytic and regulatory subunits and protein
CC       phosphatase 1 (PP1) to the KCNQ1-KCNE1 complex, allowing PKA-
CC       mediated phosphorylation and increase of delayed rectifier
CC       potassium channel activity. Interacts with KCNE2; form an
CC       heterooligomer complex that targets to the membrane raft and
CC       leading to currents with an apparently instantaneous activation, a
CC       rapid deactivation process and a linear current-voltage
CC       relationship and decreases the amplitude of the outward current.
CC       Interacts with AP2M1; mediates estrogen-induced internalization
CC       via clathrin-coated vesicles. Interacts with NEDD4L; promotes
CC       internalization and decreases I(Ks) currents. Interacts with USP2;
CC       counteracts the NEDD4L-specific down-regulation of I(Ks) and
CC       restore plasma membrane localization. Heterotetramer with KCNQ5;
CC       has a voltage-gated potassium channel activity. Interacts with
CC       KCNE3; alters membrane raft localization. Interacts with KCNE4;
CC       impairs KCNQ1 localization in lipid rafts and inhibits voltage-
CC       gated potassium channel activity. Interacts with KCNE5; impairs
CC       KCNQ1 localization in lipid rafts and only conducts current upon
CC       strong and continued depolarization (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P51787, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8900282}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P51787}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P51787}. Cytoplasmic vesicle membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P51787}. Early endosome
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P51787}. Membrane raft
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P51787}. Endoplasmic reticulum
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P51787}. Basolateral cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P51787}. Note=Colocalized with KCNE3 at the
CC       plasma membrane. Upon 17beta-oestradiol treatment, colocalizes
CC       with RAB5A at early endosome. Heterotetramer with KCNQ5 is highly
CC       retained at the endoplasmic reticulum and is localized outside of
CC       lipid raft microdomains. During the early stages of epithelial
CC       cell polarization induced by the calcium switch it removed from
CC       plasma membrane to the endoplasmic reticulum where it retained and
CC       it is redistributed to the basolateral cell surface in a PI3K-
CC       dependent manner at a later stage. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P51787}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=I;
CC         IsoId=P97414-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=II;
CC         IsoId=P97414-2; Sequence=VSP_011748, VSP_000983;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in heart, kidney and salivary
CC       glands. Detected in the cochlea. Almost undetectable in brain,
CC       skeletal muscle and liver. Widely expressed in embryonic and
CC       neonatal tissues. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9618174}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and is
CC       characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids at
CC       every third position. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P51787}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The coiled-coil domain mediates tetramerization.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P51787}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S6 is involved in the inhibition of voltage-
CC       gated potassium channel activity by KCNE4.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P51787}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The C-terminal assembly domain promotes self-interactiona;
CC       allows functional channel. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P51787}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation at Ser-27 by PKA; increases delayed rectifier
CC       potassium channel activity of the KCNQ1-KCNE1 complex through a
CC       macromolecular complex that includes PKA, PP1, and the targeting
CC       protein AKAP9. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P51787}.
CC   -!- PTM: Ubiquitinated by NEDD4L; promotes internalization. The
CC       ubiquitinylated form is internalized through a clathrin-mediated
CC       endocytosis by interacting with AP2M1 and is recycled back to the
CC       cell membrane via RAB4A and RAB11A.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P51787}.
CC   -!- PTM: Deubiquitinated by USP2; counteracts the NEDD4L-specific
CC       down-regulation of I(Ks) and restores the membrane localization.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P51787}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Mice lacking Kcnq1 show an intestinal
CC       absorption impairment which is associated with reduced serum
CC       vitamin B12 concentrations, mild macrocytic anemia, and fecal loss
CC       of sodium and potassium ions (PubMed:16314573). Mice lacking Kcnq1
CC       show microvillar secretory membranes intact, but basal acid
CC       secretion is absent and forskolin-stimulated acid output is
CC       reduced by approximately 90% in gastric mucosa (PubMed:19491250).
CC       Homozygous Kcnq1 mice develop normally and are viable, demonstrate
CC       hyperactivity, circling, and nodding behaviors; exhibit no
CC       electrocardiographic abnormalities but present a complete
CC       deafness, as well as circular movement and repetitive falling;
CC       show severe anatomic disruption of the cochlear and vestibular end
CC       organs; also display threefold enlargement by weight of the
CC       stomach resulting from mucous neck cell hyperplasia
CC       (PubMed:11120752). Mice neonates lacking Kcnq1 display
CC       significantly prolonged QT intervals during baseline ECG
CC       assessments which significantly increased following isoproterenol
CC       challenge; furthermore, the slow delayed rectifier potassium
CC       current (IKs) is absent (PubMed:15004216).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11120752, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15004216,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16314573, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19491250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. KQT (TC
CC       1.A.1.15) subfamily. Kv7.1/KCNQ1 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAB36518.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally extended.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RP   FUNCTION.

RN   [5]
RP   FUNCTION, PHOSPHORYLATION AT THR-787, MUTAGENESIS OF THR-787, AND
RP   TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=11980904; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M201949200;
RA   Wang Z., Wilson G.F., Griffith L.C.;
RT   "Calcium/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase II phosphorylates and
RT   regulates the Drosophila eag potassium channel.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 277:24022-24029(2002).
RN   [6]
RP   FUNCTION, INTERACTION WITH CASK, AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=15901771; DOI=10.1523/JNEUROSCI.4566-04.2005;
RA   Marble D.D., Hegle A.P., Snyder E.D. II, Dimitratos S., Bryant P.J.,
RA   Wilson G.F.;
RT   "Camguk/CASK enhances Ether-a-go-go potassium current by a
RT   phosphorylation-dependent mechanism.";
RL   J. Neurosci. 25:4898-4907(2005).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Structural component of a potassium channel. Mediates
CC       the potassium permeability of membranes; potassium current is
CC       regulated by CaMKII and CASK. Has a role in growth of the
CC       perineurial glial layer of the larval peripheral nerve.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11517334, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11980904,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15901771, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1840699}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The voltage-dependent potassium channel is a
CC       heterotetramer of potassium channel proteins (By similarity).
CC       Interaction with CASK. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q24210:CASK; NbExp=10; IntAct=EBI-85304, EBI-214423;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15901771};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15901771}.
CC       Note=Eag recruits CASK to the plasma membrane.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in the axon and the terminal boutons
CC       of motor neurons. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11980904}.
CC   -!- PTM: When in complex with CASK, the efficiency of Thr-787
CC       phosphorylation is increased. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11980904}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Increased growth of the perineurial glial
CC       layer of the larval peripheral nerve. Hyperexcitability at the
CC       larval neuromuscular junction (NMJ) and memory formation defects
CC       in the adult. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1840699}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and
CC       is characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids at
CC       every third position.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The segment H5 is thought to line the channel pore.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. H (Eag) (TC
CC       1.A.1.20) subfamily. Eag sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RP   DOMAIN CALCIUM BOWL, AND MUTAGENESIS OF 1002-ASP--ASP-1006.
RX   PubMed=11274367; DOI=10.1073/pnas.081072398;
RA   Bian S., Favre I., Moczydlowski E.;
RT   "Ca2+-binding activity of a COOH-terminal fragment of the Drosophila
RT   BK channel involved in Ca2+-dependent activation.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 98:4776-4781(2001).
RN   [13]
RP   PHOSPHORYLATION.
RX   PubMed=12019304;
RA   Zhou Y., Wang J., Wen H., Kucherovsky O., Levitan I.B.;
RT   "Modulation of Drosophila slowpoke calcium-dependent potassium channel
RT   activity by bound protein kinase a catalytic subunit.";
RL   J. Neurosci. 22:3855-3863(2002).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Potassium channel activated by both membrane
CC       depolarization or increase in cytosolic Ca(2+) that mediates
CC       export of K(+). Its activation dampens the excitatory events that
CC       elevate the cytosolic Ca(2+) concentration and/or depolarize the
CC       cell membrane. It therefore contributes to repolarization of the
CC       membrane potential. Kinetics are determined by alternative
CC       splicing, phosphorylation status and its combination interaction
CC       with Slob and 14-3-3-zeta. While the interaction with Slob1 alone
CC       increases its activity, its interaction with both Slob1 and 14-3-
CC       3-zeta decreases its activity. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1497890,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:1857984}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer; which constitutes the calcium-activated
CC       potassium channel (By similarity). Interacts with Slip1. Interacts
CC       with Slob, and, indirectly with 14-3-3-zeta via its interaction
CC       with Slob. Interacts with Pka-C1 and Src kinases, which can bind
CC       simultaneously to it. {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10234050,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9502797, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9539129}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P12370:Pka-C1; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-426805, EBI-82224;
CC       Q8MR31:Slip1; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-426805, EBI-123875;
CC       Q8IPH9-1:Slob; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-426805, EBI-424896;
CC       P00528:Src64B; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-426805, EBI-87092;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=20;
CC         Comment=Additional isoforms seem to exist.;
CC       Name=N;
CC         IsoId=Q03720-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q03720-2; Sequence=VSP_050267, VSP_050268;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q03720-4; Sequence=VSP_050268;
CC       Name=5;
CC         IsoId=Q03720-6; Sequence=VSP_010001, VSP_010002, VSP_050267,
CC                                  VSP_050268;
CC       Name=6;
CC         IsoId=Q03720-3; Sequence=VSP_009999, VSP_010000, VSP_010001,
CC                                  VSP_010003, VSP_050268;
CC       Name=A; Synonyms=G;
CC         IsoId=Q03720-5; Sequence=VSP_010004;
CC       Name=B;
CC         IsoId=Q03720-7; Sequence=VSP_009999;
CC       Name=C;
CC         IsoId=Q03720-8; Sequence=VSP_009999, VSP_010002;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=D;
CC         IsoId=Q03720-9; Sequence=VSP_020625, VSP_010004;
CC       Name=E;
CC         IsoId=Q03720-10; Sequence=VSP_010000, VSP_010004;
CC       Name=F;
CC         IsoId=Q03720-11; Sequence=VSP_010001, VSP_010004;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=H;
CC         IsoId=Q03720-12; Sequence=VSP_010002, VSP_010004;
CC       Name=I;
CC         IsoId=Q03720-13; Sequence=VSP_050267;
CC       Name=J;
CC         IsoId=Q03720-14; Sequence=VSP_020627;
CC       Name=K;
CC         IsoId=Q03720-15; Sequence=VSP_020628;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=L;
CC         IsoId=Q03720-16; Sequence=VSP_020626;
CC       Name=M;
CC         IsoId=Q03720-17; Sequence=VSP_010004, VSP_050268;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=O;
CC         IsoId=Q03720-18; Sequence=VSP_010002, VSP_020628;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=P;
CC         IsoId=Q03720-19; Sequence=VSP_010000, VSP_010002, VSP_020628;
CC       Name=Q;
CC         IsoId=Q03720-20; Sequence=VSP_010000, VSP_010002, VSP_010004;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in muscle cells, neurons of the CNS
CC       and PNS, mushroom bodies, a limited number of cells in embryonic
CC       and larval midgut and in epithelial-derived tracheal cells. During
CC       pupariation and embryogenesis, it is expressed in muscles many
CC       hours prior to the appearance of functional channels.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7666207, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8774450}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The S4 segment, which is characterized by a series of
CC       positively charged amino acids at every third position, is part of
CC       the voltage-sensor. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The pore-forming domain (also referred as P region) is
CC       imbedded into the membrane, and forms the selectivity filter of
CC       the pore. It contains the signature sequence of potassium channels
CC       that displays selectivity to potassium (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The RCK N-terminal domain mediates the
CC       homotetramerization, thereby promoting the assembly of monomers
CC       into functional potassium channel. It includes binding sites for
CC       Ca(2+) and Mg(2+) (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The calcium bowl constitutes one of the Ca(2+) sensors and
CC       probably acts as a Ca(2+)-binding site.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11274367}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated. Phosphorylation may be mediated by both PKA
CC       and SRC kinases, which activate the channel activity.
CC       Phosphorylation by PKA is however unclear. Indeed, although
CC       modulation of channel activity requires Pka-C1, it does not
CC       interacts with the whole PKA holoenzyme. Moreover, modulation of
CC       activity does not depend upon phosphorylation of Ser-978.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10234050, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12019304}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. Calcium-
CC       activated (TC 1.A.1.3) subfamily. Slo sub-subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAA28902.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally shortened.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=AAO45232.1; Type=Frameshift; Positions=192; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RP   INTERACTION WITH RAB11B.
RX   PubMed=22935415; DOI=10.1016/j.bbrc.2012.08.067;
RA   Sokolowski S., Harvey M., Sakai Y., Jordan A., Sokolowski B.;
RT   "The large conductance calcium-activated K(+) channel interacts with
RT   the small GTPase Rab11b.";
RL   Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 426:221-225(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Potassium channel activated by both membrane
CC       depolarization or increase in cytosolic Ca(2+) that mediates
CC       export of K(+). It is also activated by the concentration of
CC       cytosolic Mg(2+). Its activation dampens the excitatory events
CC       that elevate the cytosolic Ca(2+) concentration and/or depolarize
CC       the cell membrane. It therefore contributes to repolarization of
CC       the membrane potential. Plays a key role in controlling
CC       excitability in a number of systems, such as regulation of the
CC       contraction of smooth muscle, the tuning of hair cells in the
CC       cochlea, regulation of transmitter release, and innate immunity.
CC       In smooth muscles, its activation by high level of Ca(2+), caused
CC       by ryanodine receptors in the sarcoplasmic reticulum, regulates
CC       the membrane potential. In cochlea cells, its number and kinetic
CC       properties partly determine the characteristic frequency of each
CC       hair cell and thereby helps to establish a tonotopic map. Kinetics
CC       of KCNMA1 channels are determined by alternative splicing,
CC       phosphorylation status and its combination with modulating beta
CC       subunits. Highly sensitive to both iberiotoxin (IbTx) and
CC       charybdotoxin (CTX). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7687074}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Ethanol and carbon monoxide-bound heme increase
CC       channel activation. Heme inhibits channel activation (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer; which constitutes the calcium-activated
CC       potassium channel. Interacts with beta subunits KCNMB1, KCNMB2,
CC       KCNMB3 and KCNMB4. Interacts with gamma subunits LRRC26, LRRC38,
CC       LRRC52 and LRRC55. Beta and gamma subunits are accessory, and
CC       modulate its activity (By similarity). Interacts with RAB11B.
CC       {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10804197,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22935415}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P63260:Actg1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-1633915, EBI-351301;
CC       P48036:Anxa5; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-1633915, EBI-1184119;
CC       Q00623:Apoa1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-1633915, EBI-1634106;
CC       P08251:ATP1B1 (xeno); NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-1633915, EBI-7206371;
CC       P62204:Calm3; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-1633915, EBI-397460;
CC       P46109:CRKL (xeno); NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-1633915, EBI-910;
CC       Q14247:CTTN (xeno); NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-1633915, EBI-351886;
CC       Q60598:Cttn; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-1633915, EBI-397955;
CC       P16858:Gapdh; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-1633915, EBI-444871;
CC       O75791:GRAP2 (xeno); NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-1633915, EBI-740418;
CC       P84075:Hpca; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-1633915, EBI-2128343;
CC       Q8CAE3:Kcnmb1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-15575817, EBI-15575793;
CC       O88952:Lin7c; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-1633915, EBI-821316;
CC       P27573:Mpz; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-1633915, EBI-1634589;
CC       P61982:Ywhag; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-1633915, EBI-359843;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000250}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=5;
CC         Comment=May be partially controlled by hormonal stress.
CC         Additional isoforms seem to exist.;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q08460-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q08460-2; Sequence=VSP_009960, VSP_009961, VSP_009962,
CC                                  VSP_009964, VSP_009965;
CC         Note=Contains a phosphothreonine at position 670. Contains a
CC         phosphoserine at position 672. {ECO:0000244|PubMed:21183079};
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q08460-3; Sequence=VSP_009961, VSP_009964;
CC       Name=4; Synonyms=STREX-1;
CC         IsoId=Q08460-4; Sequence=VSP_009961, VSP_009963, VSP_009964;
CC       Name=5;
CC         IsoId=Q08460-5; Sequence=VSP_009959;
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The S0 segment is essential for the modulation by the
CC       accessory beta subunits KCNMB1, KCNMB2, KCNMB3 and KCNMB4.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The S4 segment, which is characterized by a series of
CC       positively charged amino acids at every third position, is part of
CC       the voltage-sensor.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The pore-forming domain (also referred as P region) is
CC       imbedded into the membrane, and forms the selectivity filter of
CC       the pore. It contains the signature sequence of potassium channels
CC       that displays selectivity to potassium.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The RCK N-terminal domain mediates the
CC       homotetramerization, thereby promoting the assembly of monomers
CC       into functional potassium channel. It includes binding sites for
CC       Ca(2+) and Mg(2+).
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The calcium bowl constitutes one of the Ca(2+) sensors and
CC       probably acts as a Ca(2+)-binding site. There are however other
CC       Ca(2+) sensors regions required for activation of the channel.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The heme-binding motif mediates inhibition of channel
CC       activation by heme. Carbon monoxide-bound heme leads to increased
CC       channel activation (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated (Probable). Phosphorylation by kinases such as
CC       PKA and/or PKG. In smooth muscles, phosphorylation affects its
CC       activity. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- PTM: Palmitoylation by ZDHHC22 and ZDHHC23 within the
CC       intracellular linker between the S0 and S1 transmembrane domains
CC       regulates localization to the plasma membrane. Depalmitoylated by
CC       LYPLA1 and LYPLAL1, leading to retard exit from the trans-Golgi
CC       network (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The protein was initially thought to contain two
CC       functionally distinct parts: The core channel (from the N-terminus
CC       to the S9 segment) that mediates the channel activity, and the
CC       cytoplasmic tail (from the S9 segment to the C-terminus) that
CC       mediates the calcium sensing. The situation is however more
CC       complex, since the core channel contains binding sites for Ca(2+)
CC       and Mg(2+).
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. Calcium-
CC       activated (TC 1.A.1.3) subfamily. KCa1.1/KCNMA1 sub-subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAA50215.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RP   FUNCTION, TISSUE SPECIFICITY, AND INDUCTION.
RX   PubMed=15599592; DOI=10.1007/s00425-004-1437-9;
RA   Fuchs I., Stoelzle S., Ivashikina N., Hedrich R.;
RT   "Rice K+ uptake channel OsAKT1 is sensitive to salt stress.";
RL   Planta 221:212-221(2005).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Highly selective inward-rectifying potassium channel
CC       that mediates potassium uptake by plant roots. Assuming opened or
CC       closed conformations in response to the voltage difference across
CC       the membrane, the channel is activated by hyperpolarization. May
CC       be a major salt-sensitive potassium channel in roots.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15599592}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The potassium channel is probably a homo- or
CC       heterotetrameric complex of pore-forming subunits. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in roots and coleoptile of young
CC       seedlings. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15599592}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Down-regulated by salt stress.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15599592}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and is
CC       characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids. The
CC       pore-forming region H5 is enclosed by the transmembrane segments
CC       S5 and S6 in the Shaker-type (1P/6TM) and contains the GYGD
CC       signature motif which seems to be involved in potassium
CC       selectivity (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The KHA domain (rich in hydrophobic and acidic residues)
CC       present in the C-terminal part is likely to be important for
CC       tetramerization. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. Plant (TC
CC       1.A.1.4) subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AK120308; Type=Frameshift; Positions=769; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RN   [56]
RP   VARIANT LQT2 PRO-744, AND CHARACTERIZATION OF VARIANT LQT2 PRO-744.
RX   PubMed=22314138; DOI=10.1016/j.bbrc.2012.01.118;
RA   Aidery P., Kisselbach J., Gaspar H., Baldea I., Schweizer P.A.,
RA   Becker R., Katus H.A., Thomas D.;
RT   "Identification and functional characterization of the novel human
RT   ether-a-go-go-related gene (hERG) R744P mutant associated with
RT   hereditary long QT syndrome 2.";
RL   Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 418:830-835(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Pore-forming (alpha) subunit of voltage-gated inwardly
CC       rectifying potassium channel. Channel properties are modulated by
CC       cAMP and subunit assembly. Mediates the rapidly activating
CC       component of the delayed rectifying potassium current in heart
CC       (IKr) (PubMed:18559421, PubMed:26363003, PubMed:27916661).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18559421, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26363003,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27916661}.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Isoform A-USO: Has no channel activity by itself, but
CC       modulates channel characteristics by forming heterotetramers with
CC       other isoforms which are retained intracellularly and undergo
CC       ubiquitin-dependent degradation. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18559421}.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Isoform B-USO: Has no channel activity by itself, but
CC       modulates channel characteristics by forming heterotetramers with
CC       other isoforms which are retained intracellularly and undergo
CC       ubiquitin-dependent degradation. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18559421}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The potassium channel is probably composed of a homo- or
CC       heterotetrameric complex of pore-forming alpha subunits that can
CC       associate with modulating beta subunits (PubMed:27916661).
CC       Interacts with DNAJB12 and DNAJB14; chaperones DNAJB12 and DNAJB14
CC       promote tetramerization (PubMed:27916661). Heteromultimer with
CC       KCNH6/ERG2 and KCNH7/ERG3 (By similarity). Interacts with ALG10B
CC       (By similarity). Heteromultimer with KCNE1 and KCNE2
CC       (PubMed:9230439, PubMed:10219239). Interacts with CANX
CC       (PubMed:16361248). The core-glycosylated, but not the fully
CC       glycosylated form interacts with RNF207 (PubMed:25281747).
CC       Interacts with NDFIP1 and NDFIP2 (PubMed:26363003).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O08962, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10219239,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16361248, ECO:0000269|PubMed:25281747,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26363003, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27916661,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9230439}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-720643, EBI-720643;
CC       Q03135:CAV1; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-720643, EBI-603614;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18559421,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19412172, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26363003}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18559421,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19412172}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=6;
CC         Comment=Experimental confirmation may be lacking for some
CC         isoforms.;
CC       Name=A;
CC         IsoId=Q12809-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=B;
CC         IsoId=Q12809-2; Sequence=VSP_000965;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=Q12809-4; Sequence=VSP_000966;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=A-USO;
CC         IsoId=Q12809-5; Sequence=VSP_047880, VSP_047881;
CC         Note=Twice more abundant than isoform 1 in heart.;
CC       Name=B-USO;
CC         IsoId=Q12809-6; Sequence=VSP_047878, VSP_047879, VSP_047880,
CC                                  VSP_047881;
CC       Name=3.1;
CC         IsoId=Q12809-7; Sequence=VSP_047877;
CC         Note=Primate-specific. Lacks a domain that is crucial for slow
CC         channel deactivation.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Highly expressed in heart and brain. Isoforms
CC       USO are frequently overexpressed in cancer cells.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18559421}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Up-regulated by RNF207 (at protein level).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25281747}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and is
CC       characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids at
CC       every third position.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated on serine and threonine residues.
CC       Phosphorylation by PKA inhibits ion conduction.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10837251}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Long QT syndrome 2 (LQT2) [MIM:613688]: A heart disorder
CC       characterized by a prolonged QT interval on the ECG and
CC       polymorphic ventricular arrhythmias. They cause syncope and sudden
CC       death in response to exercise or emotional stress, and can present
CC       with a sentinel event of sudden cardiac death in infancy. Deafness
CC       is often associated with long QT syndrome type 2.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10086971, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10187793,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10220144, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10517660,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10735633, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10753933,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10862094, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10973849,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11170080, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12062363,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12354768, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12442276,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12621127, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15051636,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15840476, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16361248,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16414944, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16922724,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19716085, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22314138,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27916661, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7889573,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8635257, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8877771,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8914737, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9024139,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9452080, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9544837,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9600240, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9693036}. Note=The
CC       disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in
CC       this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Short QT syndrome 1 (SQT1) [MIM:609620]: A heart disorder
CC       characterized by idiopathic persistently and uniformly short QT
CC       interval on ECG in the absence of structural heart disease in
CC       affected individuals. It causes syncope and sudden death.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14676148, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15828882}.
CC       Note=The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene
CC       represented in this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. H (Eag) (TC
CC       1.A.1.20) subfamily. Kv11.1/KCNH2 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC       Sequence=CAA09232.1; Type=Erroneous gene model prediction; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
