CC   -!- FUNCTION: Functions as a cation channel involved in fluid-flow
CC       mechanosensation by the primary cilium in renal epithelium
CC       (PubMed:18695040). Functions as outward-rectifying K(+) channel,
CC       but is also permeable to Ca(2+), and to a much lesser degree also
CC       to Na(+) (PubMed:11854751, PubMed:15692563, PubMed:27071085,
CC       PubMed:27991905). May contribute to the release of Ca(2+) stores
CC       from the endoplasmic reticulum (PubMed:11854751, PubMed:20881056).
CC       Together with TRPV4, forms mechano- and thermosensitive channels
CC       in cilium (PubMed:18695040). PKD1 and PKD2 may function through a
CC       common signaling pathway that is necessary to maintain the normal,
CC       differentiated state of renal tubule cells. Acts as a regulator of
CC       cilium length, together with PKD1. The dynamic control of cilium
CC       length is essential in the regulation of mechanotransductive
CC       signaling. The cilium length response creates a negative feedback
CC       loop whereby fluid shear-mediated deflection of the primary
CC       cilium, which decreases intracellular cAMP, leads to cilium
CC       shortening and thus decreases flow-induced signaling. Also
CC       involved in left-right axis specification via its role in sensing
CC       nodal flow; forms a complex with PKD1L1 in cilia to facilitate
CC       flow detection in left-right patterning. Detection of asymmetric
CC       nodal flow gives rise to a Ca(2+) signal that is required for
CC       normal, asymmetric expression of genes involved in the
CC       specification of body left-right laterality (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O35245, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11854751,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15692563, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16551655,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18695040, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20881056,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27991905, ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Channnel activity is regulated by
CC       phosphorylation (PubMed:16551655, PubMed:20881056,
CC       PubMed:26269590). Channnel activity is regulated by intracellular
CC       Ca(2+) (PubMed:11854751). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11854751,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16551655, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20881056,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26269590}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer (PubMed:20881056, PubMed:27768895,
CC       PubMed:27991905, PubMed:28092368). Interacts with PKD1, giving
CC       rise to a complex formed by one PKD1 chain and a PKD2 homooligomer
CC       (PubMed:20881056, PubMed:19556541). In vitro results suggest
CC       assembly of a complex composed of one PKD1 chain and a PKD2
CC       trimer; the physiological significance of this is uncertain
CC       (PubMed:19556541). Isoform 1 interacts with PKD1 while isoform 3
CC       does not (By similarity). Interacts with PKD1L1. PKD1 requires the
CC       presence of PKD2 for stable expression (By similarity). Interacts
CC       with CD2AP (PubMed:10913159). Interacts with HAX1
CC       (PubMed:10760273). Interacts with NEK8 (By similarity). Part of a
CC       complex containing AKAP5, ADCY5, ADCY6 and PDE4C (By similarity).
CC       Interacts (via C-terminus) with TRPV4 (via C-terminus)
CC       (PubMed:18695040). Interacts (via C-terminal acidic region) with
CC       PACS1 and PACS2; these interactions retain the protein in the
CC       endoplasmic reticulum and prevent trafficking to the cell membrane
CC       (PubMed:15692563). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O35245,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10760273, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10913159,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15692563, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18695040,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19556541, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20881056,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27768895, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27991905,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:28092368}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=8; IntAct=EBI-7813714, EBI-7813714;
CC       O35387:Hax1 (xeno); NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-7813714, EBI-642449;
CC       Q02363:ID2; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-7813714, EBI-713450;
CC       Q91908:itpr1 (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-7813714, EBI-9633447;
CC       Q6A162:KRT40; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-7813714, EBI-10171697;
CC       P60410:KRTAP10-8; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-7813714, EBI-10171774;
CC       P43361:MAGEA8; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-7813714, EBI-10182930;
CC       P98161:PKD1; NbExp=8; IntAct=EBI-7813714, EBI-1752013;
CC       P98161-3:PKD1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-9837017, EBI-15930070;
CC       O08852:Pkd1 (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-9837017, EBI-6666305;
CC       O15162:PLSCR1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-7813714, EBI-740019;
CC       J9P3Y7:RYR2 (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-9837017, EBI-15630134;
CC       P48995:TRPC1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-7813714, EBI-929665;
CC       P48995-2:TRPC1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-7813714, EBI-9830970;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell projection, cilium membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18695040, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20881056,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27259053}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27768895, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27991905,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:28092368}. Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10760273, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11854751,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15692563, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20881056,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:28092368, ECO:0000305|PubMed:10913159}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27768895,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27991905, ECO:0000269|PubMed:28092368}. Cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15692563,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19556541, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26269590,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27071085, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27259053,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:28092368}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27768895, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27991905,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:28092368}. Basolateral cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10770959}. Cytoplasmic vesicle membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10770959}. Note=Retained in the endoplasmic
CC       reticulum by interaction with PACS1 and PACS2 (PubMed:15692563).
CC       Detected on kidney tubule basolateral membranes and basal
CC       cytoplasmic vesicles (PubMed:10770959). Cell surface and cilium
CC       localization requires GANAB (PubMed:27259053).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15692563, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27259053}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=5;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q13563-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=delta6;
CC         IsoId=Q13563-2; Sequence=VSP_042479, VSP_042480;
CC       Name=3; Synonyms=delta7;
CC         IsoId=Q13563-3; Sequence=VSP_042481;
CC       Name=4; Synonyms=delta9;
CC         IsoId=Q13563-4; Sequence=VSP_042482, VSP_042483;
CC       Name=5; Synonyms=delta12/13;
CC         IsoId=Q13563-5; Sequence=VSP_042484;
CC         Note=Minor isoform.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in fetal and adult kidney
CC       (PubMed:10770959). Detected at the thick ascending limb of the
CC       loop of Henle, at distal tubules, including the distal convoluted
CC       tubule and cortical collecting tubules, with weak staining of the
CC       collecting duct (PubMed:10770959). Detected on placenta
CC       syncytiotrophoblasts (at protein level) (PubMed:26269590).
CC       Strongly expressed in ovary, fetal and adult kidney, testis, and
CC       small intestine. Not detected in peripheral leukocytes.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10770959, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26269590,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8650545}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The C-terminal coiled-coil domain is involved in
CC       oligomerization and the interaction with PKD1 (PubMed:18694932,
CC       PubMed:19556541). The isolated coiled-coil domain forms a
CC       homotrimer in vitro; the homotrimer interacts with a single PKD1
CC       chain (PubMed:19556541). The coiled-coil domain binds calcium and
CC       undergoes a calcium-induced conformation change (in vitro)
CC       (PubMed:18694932). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18694932,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19556541}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated. Phosphorylation is important for protein
CC       function; a mutant that lacks the N-terminal phosphorylation sites
CC       cannot complement a zebrafish pkd2-deficient mutant
CC       (PubMed:16551655). PKD-mediated phosphorylation at the C-terminus
CC       regulates its function in the release of Ca(2+) stores from the
CC       endoplasmic reticulum (PubMed:20881056). PKA-mediated
CC       phosphorylation at a C-terminal site strongly increases the open
CC       probability of the channel, but does not increase single channel
CC       conductance (PubMed:26269590). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16551655,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20881056, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26269590}.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylated. The four subunits in a tetramer probably
CC       differ in the extent of glycosylation; simultaneous glycosylation
CC       of all experimentally validated sites would probably create steric
CC       hindrance. Thus, glycosylation at Asn-305 is not compatible with
CC       glycosylation at Asn-328; only one of these two residues is
CC       glycosylated at a given time. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:28092368}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Polycystic kidney disease 2 (PKD2) [MIM:613095]: A
CC       disorder characterized by progressive formation and enlargement of
CC       cysts in both kidneys, typically leading to end-stage renal
CC       disease in adult life. Cysts also occurs in the liver and other
CC       organs. It represents approximately 15% of the cases of autosomal
CC       dominant polycystic kidney disease. PKD2 is clinically milder than
CC       PKD1 but it has a deleterious impact on overall life expectancy.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10411676, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10541293,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10835625, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11854751,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11968093, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12707387,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14993477, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15772804,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21115670, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27071085,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9326320}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The mechanisms that govern channel opening are
CC       complex and still under debate; heterologous expression of PKD2 by
CC       itself or together with PKD1 gives rise to very low or
CC       undetectable spontaneous ion channel activity, in spite of its
CC       presence at the cell membrane. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19556541,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27768895}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the polycystin family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC       URL="http://www.functionalglycomics.org/glycomics/GBPServlet?&operationType=view&cbpId=cbp_hum_Ctlect_205";

RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=25756792; DOI=10.1371/journal.pone.0116599;
RA   Duarri A., Nibbeling E.A., Fokkens M.R., Meijer M., Boerrigter M.,
RA   Verschuuren-Bemelmans C.C., Kremer B.P., van de Warrenburg B.P.,
RA   Dooijes D., Boddeke E., Sinke R.J., Verbeek D.S.;
RT   "Functional analysis helps to define KCNC3 mutational spectrum in
RT   dutch ataxia cases.";
RL   PLoS ONE 10:E0116599-E0116599(2015).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-gated potassium channel that plays an important
CC       role in the rapid repolarization of fast-firing brain neurons. The
CC       channel opens in response to the voltage difference across the
CC       membrane, forming a potassium-selective channel through which
CC       potassium ions pass in accordance with their electrochemical
CC       gradient. The channel displays rapid activation and inactivation
CC       kinetics (PubMed:10712820, PubMed:26997484, PubMed:22289912,
CC       PubMed:23734863, PubMed:16501573, PubMed:19953606,
CC       PubMed:21479265, PubMed:25756792). It plays a role in the
CC       regulation of the frequency, shape and duration of action
CC       potentials in Purkinje cells. Required for normal survival of
CC       cerebellar neurons, probably via its role in regulating the
CC       duration and frequency of action potentials that in turn regulate
CC       the activity of voltage-gated Ca(2+) channels and cellular Ca(2+)
CC       homeostasis (By similarity). Required for normal motor function
CC       (PubMed:23734863, PubMed:16501573, PubMed:19953606,
CC       PubMed:21479265, PubMed:25756792). Plays a role in the
CC       reorganization of the cortical actin cytoskeleton and the
CC       formation of actin veil structures in neuronal growth cones via
CC       its interaction with HAX1 and the Arp2/3 complex
CC       (PubMed:26997484). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q63959,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10712820, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16501573,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19953606, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21479265,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22289912, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23734863,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25756792, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26997484}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer. Heterotetramer with KCNC1
CC       (PubMed:23734863). Interacts (via C-terminus) with HAX1
CC       (PubMed:26997484). Identified in a complex with ACTR3, a subunit
CC       of the Arp2/3 complex; this interaction is indirect and depends on
CC       the presence of HAX1 (PubMed:26997484). Interaction with HAX1
CC       modulates channel gating (PubMed:26997484).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23734863, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26997484}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10712820,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16501573, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19953606,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21479265, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22289912,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23734863, ECO:0000269|PubMed:25152487,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25756792, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26997484}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000255}. Cell junction, synapse,
CC       presynaptic cell membrane {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q63959}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000255}. Perikaryon
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q63959}. Cell projection, axon
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q63959}. Cell projection, dendrite
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q63959}. Cell projection, dendritic spine
CC       membrane {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q01956}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000255}. Cytoplasm, cell cortex
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26997484}. Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26997484}. Note=Detected on Purkinje cell
CC       dendritic spines (By similarity). Detected at presynaptic calices
CC       of Held (By similarity). Colocalizes with the cortical actin
CC       cytoskeleton and the Arp2/3 complex (PubMed:26997484).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q01956, ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q63959,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26997484}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and is
CC       characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids at
CC       every third position. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The cytoplasmic N-terminus mediates N-type inactivation.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26997484}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The C-terminal cytoplasmic tail contributes to the
CC       regulation of channel inactivation and to the interaction with
CC       HAX1 and the Arp2/3 complex. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26997484}.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylated. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25152487}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Spinocerebellar ataxia 13 (SCA13) [MIM:605259]:
CC       Spinocerebellar ataxia is a clinically and genetically
CC       heterogeneous group of cerebellar disorders. Patients show
CC       progressive incoordination of gait and often poor coordination of
CC       hands, speech and eye movements, due to degeneration of the
CC       cerebellum with variable involvement of the brainstem and spinal
CC       cord. SCA13 is an autosomal dominant cerebellar ataxia (ADCA)
CC       characterized by slow progression and variable age at onset,
CC       ranging from childhood to late adulthood. Mental retardation can
CC       be present in some patients. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16501573,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19953606, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21479265,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22289912, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23734863,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25152487, ECO:0000269|PubMed:25756792}.
CC       Note=The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene
CC       represented in this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. C (Shaw) (TC
CC       1.A.1.2) subfamily. Kv3.3/KCNC3 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Held K., Pascaud F., Eckert C., Gajdanowicz P., Hashimoto K.,

RN   [16]
RP   INTERACTION WITH SLAC1.
RX   PubMed=27002025; DOI=10.1105/tpc.16.01050;
RA   Zhang A., Ren H.M., Tan Y.Q., Qi G.N., Yao F.Y., Wu G.L., Yang L.W.,
RA   Hussain J., Sun S.J., Wang Y.F.;
RT   "S-type anion channels SLAC1 and SLAH3 function as essential negative
RT   regulators of inward K+ channels and stomatal opening in
RT   Arabidopsis.";
RL   Plant Cell 0:0-0(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Highly selective and weak inward-rectifying potassium
CC       channel. Plays a role in both loading and unloading potassium
CC       into/from the phloem sap. Seems to control sugar loading into
CC       phloem via a voltage-dependent process. Blocked by physiological
CC       concentrations of external calcium and by external acidification.
CC       May interact with the cytoskeleton or with regulatory proteins.
CC       Dephosphorylation by PP2CA not only leads to the inhibition of
CC       potassium currents but also to an increase of the voltage-
CC       dependence of the channel. Regulated by the CBL4/CIPK6 calcium
CC       sensor/protein kinase complex via a kinase interaction-dependent
CC       but phosphorylation-independent translocation of the channel to
CC       the plasma membrane. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12447548,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12678562}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The potassium channel is probably composed of a homo- or
CC       heterotetrameric complex of pore-forming subunits. Interacts with
CC       the phosphatase PPC2A and the kinase CIPK6. May interact with
CC       AKT1, KAT1 and KAT3. Interacts with SLAC1 (PubMed:27002025).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11181729, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12034902,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12678562, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21445098,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27002025, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9916143}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-1552774, EBI-1552774;
CC       Q38998:AKT1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-1552774, EBI-974289;
CC       Q39128:KAT1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-1552774, EBI-1552490;
CC       Q38849:KAT2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-1552774, EBI-2117720;
CC       P49598:PP2CA; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-1552774, EBI-1764934;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21445098}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21445098}. Note=Targeted to the cell membrane
CC       when interacting with CIPK6 and CBL4.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed mainly in the phloem tissues
CC       throughout the plant but also, at a lower level, in leaf epiderm,
CC       mesophyll and guard cells. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10377458,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10852932, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12034902,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8552711}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: In shoots, strongly induced by abscisic acid (ABA)
CC       treatment and reduced after NaCl treatment or potassium
CC       starvation. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12678562}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and is
CC       characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids. The
CC       pore-forming region H5 is enclosed by the transmembrane segments
CC       S5 and S6 in the Shaker-type (1P/6TM) and contains the GYGD
CC       signature motif which seems to be involved in potassium
CC       selectivity.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The KHA domain (rich in hydrophobic and acidic residues)
CC       present in the C-terminal part is likely to be important for
CC       tetramerization.
CC   -!- PTM: Dephosphorylated by PP2CA.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Delayed development and flowering.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21445098}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. Plant (TC
CC       1.A.1.4) subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAA96153.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally extended.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=AAA96154.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally extended.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=CAA16770.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally extended.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=CAB79175.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally extended.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RN   [20]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.87 ANGSTROMS) OF 518-702.
RA   Chaves-Sanjuan A., Gonzalez-Rubio J.M., Sanchez-Barrena M.J.,
RA   Albert A.;
RT   "Structure of the Ankyrin Domain of Akt1.";
RL   Submitted (JUL-2015) to the PDB data bank.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Highly selective inward-rectifying potassium channel
CC       that mediate potassium uptake by plant roots in response to low
CC       K(+) conditions, by a calcium-, CBL-, and CIPK-dependent pathway.
CC       Positively regulated by phosphorylation by CIPK23. Negatively
CC       regulated by a kinase-independent regulatory mechanism involving a
CC       competing direct binding of CBL10. Involved in the stomatal
CC       regulation by monitoring the turgor pressure in guard cells.
CC       Assuming opened or closed conformations in response to the voltage
CC       difference across the membrane, the channel is activated by
CC       hyperpolarization. May interact with the cytoskeleton or with
CC       regulatory proteins (PubMed:12678562, PubMed:16814720,
CC       PubMed:16895985, PubMed:17898163, PubMed:9572739). Is essential
CC       with POT5/HAK5 for high-affinity potassium uptake in roots during
CC       seedling establishment and postgermination growth under low
CC       potassium conditions (PubMed:20413648).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12678562, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16814720,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16895985, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17898163,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20413648, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9572739}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The potassium channel is probably composed of a homo- or
CC       heterotetrameric complex of pore-forming subunits. Possible
CC       heteromultimer with AKT2 or KAT3. Part of a K(+)-channel calcium-
CC       sensing kinase/phosphatase complex composed by a calcium sensor
CC       CBL (CBL1, CBL2, CBL3 or CBL9), a kinase CIPK (CIPK6, CIPK16 or
CC       CIPK23), a phosphatase PP2C (AIP1) and a K(+)-channel (AKT1).
CC       Interacts directly with AIP1, CBL10, CIPK6, CIPK16 and CIPK23.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12678562, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16814720,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16895985, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17898163,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23331977, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9218788}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-974289, EBI-974289;
CC       Q38898:AKT2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-974289, EBI-1552774;
CC       Q93VD3:CIPK23; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-974289, EBI-974277;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16814720};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16814720}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Preferentially expressed in the peripheral
CC       cell layers of root mature including root cortex and root hairs.
CC       Detected also, at a lower level, in the mesophyll of the leaves
CC       and at restricted sites corresponding to hydathodes and guard
CC       cells. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8555458, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8820606}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: In roots, strongly reduced after 2,4-
CC       dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2,4-D) treatment and weakly reduced
CC       after benzyladenine (BA) treatment. In shoots, strongly reduced
CC       after abscisic acid (ABA) treatment and induced after
CC       benzyladenine (BA) treatment. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12678562}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and is
CC       characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids. The
CC       pore-forming region H5 is enclosed by the transmembrane segments
CC       S5 and S6 in the Shaker-type (1P/6TM) and contains the GYGD
CC       signature motif which seems to be involved in potassium
CC       selectivity.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The KHA domain (rich in hydrophobic and acidic residues)
CC       present in the C-terminal part is likely to be important for
CC       tetramerization.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated by CIPK proteins CIPK6, CIPK16 and CIPK23. The
CC       activation by phosphorylation is induced by low K(+) conditions
CC       and stimulates K(+) uptake and relocation. Dephosphorylation by
CC       AIP1 repressed the transport activity.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16814720, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16895985,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17898163}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. Plant (TC
CC       1.A.1.4) subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Monovalent cation channel required for maintenance of
CC       rapid intracellular calcium release. May act as a potassium
CC       counter-ion channel that functions in synchronization with calcium
CC       release from intracellular stores. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17611541}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotrimer; trimerization probably requires binding to
CC       phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:A5A6S6, ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9NA73}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Sarcoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:A5A6S6}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:A5A6S6}. Nucleus membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:A5A6S6}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed at high levels in heart and striated
CC       muscle. Also detected in brain, lung and kidney.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17611541}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Mice are viable. Mice lacking Tmem38a and
CC       Tmem38b show a weak heartbeat at E9.5 followed by loss of
CC       cardiomyocyte viability and embryonic lethality around E10.5.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17611541}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TMEM38 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Probable inward-rectifying potassium channel. Assuming
CC       opened or closed conformations in response to the voltage
CC       difference across the membrane, the channel is activated by
CC       hyperpolarization (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and is
CC       characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids. The
CC       pore-forming region H5 is enclosed by the transmembrane segments
CC       S5 and S6 in the Shaker-type (1P/6TM) and contains the GYGD
CC       signature motif which seems to be involved in potassium
CC       selectivity (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. Plant (TC
CC       1.A.1.4) subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Outwardly rectifying potassium channel subunit that may
CC       coassemble with other Slo-type channel subunits. Activated by high
CC       intracellular sodium or chloride levels. Activated upon
CC       stimulation of G-protein coupled receptors, such as CHRM1 and
CC       GRIA1. May be regulated by calcium in the absence of sodium ions
CC       (in vitro) (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts (via C-terminus) with FMR1; this interaction
CC       alters gating properties of KCNT1 (PubMed:20512134). Interacts
CC       with CRBN via its cytoplasmic C-terminus (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9Z258, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20512134}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000250}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=4;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q5JUK3-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q5JUK3-2; Sequence=VSP_015470, VSP_015471;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q5JUK3-3; Sequence=VSP_015470, VSP_015471, VSP_044476;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=Q5JUK3-4; Sequence=VSP_055700, VSP_055701, VSP_015471;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Highest expression in liver, brain and spinal
CC       cord. Lowest expression in skeletal muscle.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10718198}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated by protein kinase C. Phosphorylation of the C-
CC       terminal domain increases channel activity (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Epileptic encephalopathy, early infantile, 14 (EIEE14)
CC       [MIM:614959]: A rare epileptic encephalopathy of infancy that
CC       combines pharmacoresistant seizures with developmental delay. This
CC       severe neurologic disorder is characterized by onset in the first
CC       6 months of life of refractory focal seizures and arrest of
CC       psychomotor development. Ictal EEG shows discharges that arise
CC       randomly from various areas of both hemispheres and migrate from
CC       one brain region to another. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23086397,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23708187, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24029078,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24463883, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26993267,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27864847}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Epilepsy, nocturnal frontal lobe, 5 (ENFL5) [MIM:615005]:
CC       An autosomal dominant focal epilepsy syndrome characterized by
CC       childhood onset of clusters of motor seizures during sleep. Some
CC       patients may develop behavioral or psychiatric manifestations
CC       and/or intellectual disability. The phenotype is more severe than
CC       observed in other genetic forms of nocturnal frontal lobe
CC       epilepsy. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23086396}. Note=The disease is
CC       caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. Calcium-
CC       activated (TC 1.A.1.3) subfamily. KCa4.1/KCNT1 sub-subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=BAA92660.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally shortened.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RP   STRUCTURE BY ELECTRON MICROSCOPY (3.78 ANGSTROMS) OF 1-962 IN COMPLEX
RP   WITH CALM, FUNCTION, ENZYME REGULATION, SUBUNIT, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION,
RP   TOPOLOGY, AND GLYCOSYLATION AT ASN-388.
RX   PubMed=27516594; DOI=10.1126/science.aaf8070;
RA   Whicher J.R., MacKinnon R.;
RT   "Structure of the voltage-gated K(+) channel Eag1 reveals an
RT   alternative voltage sensing mechanism.";
RL   Science 353:664-669(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Pore-forming (alpha) subunit of a voltage-gated delayed
CC       rectifier potassium channel (PubMed:7925287, PubMed:9400421,
CC       PubMed:24495567, PubMed:27516594). Channel properties are
CC       modulated by subunit assembly. Mediates IK(NI) current in
CC       myoblasts. Involved in the regulation of cell proliferation and
CC       differentiation, in particular adipogenic and osteogenic
CC       differentiation in bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells
CC       (MSCs) (By similarity). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O95259,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24495567, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27516594,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7925287, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9400421}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Channel activity is inhibited by interaction
CC       with Ca(2+)-bound calmodulin (PubMed:27516594). Interaction of a
CC       single pore-forming alpha subunit with a calmodulin chain is
CC       sufficient to promote channel closure. Channel activity is not
CC       regulated by cyclic nucleotides. Channel activity is inhibited by
CC       binding intracellular phosphatidylinositol-3,5-bisphosphate and
CC       phosphatidylinositol-4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2), but is not inhibited
CC       by phosphatidylinositol 4-phosphate (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O95259, ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q60603,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27516594}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The potassium channel is composed of a homo- or
CC       heterotetrameric complex of pore-forming alpha subunits that can
CC       associate with modulating beta subunits (PubMed:9400421,
CC       PubMed:27516594). Heteromultimer with KCNH5/EAG2 (By similarity).
CC       Interacts with ALG10B (PubMed:9722534). Interacts with RABEP1
CC       (PubMed:22841712). Interacts (via C-terminus) with CTTN
CC       (PubMed:23144454). Interacts (via cytoplasmic region) with Ca(2+)-
CC       bound calmodulin (PubMed:27516594). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O95259,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22841712, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23144454,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27516594, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9400421,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9722534}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       O35550:Rabep1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-7991592, EBI-7991542;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24495567,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27516594, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7925287,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9400421}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27516594}. Nucleus inner membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O95259}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O95259}. Cell projection, dendrite
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24495567}. Cell projection, axon
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24495567}. Cell junction, synapse, presynaptic
CC       cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25556795}. Perikaryon
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24495567}. Cell junction, synapse,
CC       postsynaptic cell membrane, postsynaptic density
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24495567}. Early endosome membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O95259}. Note=Perinuclear KCNH1 is located
CC       to NPC-free islands. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O95259}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in cerebellum, at parallel fiber
CC       synapses on Purkinje cell spines (PubMed:25556795). Detected in
CC       hippocampus neurons (at protein level) (PubMed:24495567). Detected
CC       in brain, but not in the other tissues tested; expression is
CC       highest in granular cells of the dentate gyrus, in hippocampus CA3
CC       pyramidal cells, and in cerebellar granule cells (PubMed:7925287).
CC       Detected in pituitary (PubMed:10718922).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10718922, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24495567,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25556795, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7925287}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and is
CC       characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids at
CC       every third position. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9400421}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The C-terminal region interacts with the cyclic
CC       nucleotide-binding domain and contributes to regulate channel
CC       gating. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q60603}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The PAS and PAC domain interact with the cyclic
CC       nucleotide-binding domain and contribute to the regulation of
CC       channel gating. Calmodulin binding clamps together the PAS and PAC
CC       domain with the cyclic nucleotide-binding domain from a
CC       neighboring subunit and causes a conformation change that leads to
CC       channel closure. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27516594}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The cyclic nucleotide-binding domain lacks residues that
CC       are essential for nucleotide-binding and cannot bind cyclic
CC       nucleotides. Instead, residues from the C-terminal domain (the so-
CC       called intrinsic ligand) bind in the cavity that would be expected
CC       to bind cyclic nucleotides. Interaction with the C-terminal region
CC       hinders interaction with CALM and reduces the affinity for CALM.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q60603}.
CC   -!- PTM: Channel activity is regulated via tyrosine
CC       phosphorylation/dephosphorylation by SRC and PTPN6.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O95259}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. H (Eag) (TC
CC       1.A.1.20) subfamily. Kv10.1/KCNH1 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE, DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE, TISSUE SPECIFICITY, AND
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=26432887; DOI=10.1242/bio.014076;
RA   Roxo-Rosa M., Jacinto R., Sampaio P., Lopes S.S.;
RT   "The zebrafish Kupffer's vesicle as a model system for the molecular
RT   mechanisms by which the lack of Polycystin-2 leads to stimulation of
RT   CFTR.";
RL   Biol. Open 4:1356-1366(2015).
RN   [9]
RP   FUNCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=25660539; DOI=10.1016/j.cub.2014.12.051;
RA   Yuan S., Zhao L., Brueckner M., Sun Z.;
RT   "Intraciliary calcium oscillations initiate vertebrate left-right
RT   asymmetry.";
RL   Curr. Biol. 25:556-567(2015).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Functions as non-selective cation channel (By
CC       similarity). Required for normal oscillation of Ca(2+) levels
CC       within cilia; these oscillations of the intraciliary Ca(2+) levels
CC       can trigger cytoplasmic Ca(2+) signaling cascades
CC       (PubMed:25660539). May contribute to the release of Ca(2+) stores
CC       from the endoplasmic reticulum (By similarity). Required for
CC       normal temporal variation of the intracellular Ca(2+) levels in
CC       the heart (PubMed:23376035). Plays a role in fluid-flow
CC       mechanosensation (By similarity). Required for normal
CC       specification of the body left-right axis during embryogenesis,
CC       most likely via its role in ciliary Ca(2+) oscillations in
CC       Kupffer's vesicle (PubMed:15269167, PubMed:16216239,
CC       PubMed:16943304, PubMed:17360770, PubMed:23376035,
CC       PubMed:25660539). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O35245,
CC       ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13563, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15269167,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16216239, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16943304,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17360770, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23376035,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25660539}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Channnel activity is regulated by
CC       phosphorylation. Channnel activity is regulated by intracellular
CC       Ca(2+). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13563}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer (By similarity). Interacts with pkd1l1 (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:H2LRU7,
CC       ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13563}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Basolateral cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16943304}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13563}. Cell membrane, sarcolemma
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16943304}. Cytoplasm, myofibril, sarcomere
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16943304}. Sarcoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23376035}. Apical cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16943304}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13563}. Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:26432887}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13563}. Cell projection, cilium
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16943304, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26432887}.
CC       Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton, cilium basal body
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26432887}. Cytoplasmic vesicle membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16943304}. Note=Detected at the basolateral
CC       cell membrane and on apical, lumenal cilia in anterior, proximal
CC       pronephric ducts, and in intracellular vesicles in the posterior
CC       part of the pronephric duct. Detected on apical cell membranes on
CC       epithelial cells in the ear. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16943304}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected along cilia and at the cilium basal
CC       body in Kupffer's vesicle at the 10 somite stage
CC       (PubMed:26432887). Detected in heart at 48hpf (PubMed:23376035).
CC       Detected in muscle and pronephric kidney at 48 hpf
CC       (PubMed:16943304). Detected on trunk muscle sarcolemma and
CC       sarcomere, on ependymal cell cilia in brain, at the apical cell
CC       membrane in epithelial cells in the ear, at the lateral line organ
CC       and olfactory placode at 56 hpf (PubMed:16943304). Detected in
CC       adult kidney (at protein level) (PubMed:16943304).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16943304, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26432887}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: First detected at the onset of gastrulation
CC       in a band at the blastoderm margin (PubMed:16216239,
CC       PubMed:17360770). Ubiquitous during gastrulation, somatogenesis
CC       and at 48 hpf (PubMed:16943304). During gastrulation, detected at
CC       the hypoblast of the dorsal midline and in dorsal forerunner cells
CC       that form a ciliated Kupffer's vesicle later on (PubMed:16216239,
CC       PubMed:17360770, PubMed:26432887). Ubiquitous during early somite
CC       stages, with high levels of expression in Kupffer's vesicle
CC       (PubMed:16216239, PubMed:17360770). At subsequent stages, detected
CC       in pronephric duct primordia and neural floorplate
CC       (PubMed:16216239, PubMed:16943304, PubMed:17360770,
CC       PubMed:26432887). Highly expressed in brain at 24 hpf
CC       (PubMed:16216239). At 3 dpf, detected at pharyngeal arches and the
CC       pectoral fin bud (PubMed:16216239). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16216239,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16943304, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17360770,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26432887}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The C-terminal coiled-coil domain is involved in
CC       oligomerization. The coiled-coil domain binds calcium and
CC       undergoes a calcium-induced conformation change (in vitro).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13563}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated. Phosphorylation is important for protein
CC       function; a mutant human construct that lacks the N-terminal
CC       phosphorylation sites cannot complement a zebrafish pkd2-deficient
CC       mutant. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16551655}.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylated. The four subunits in a tetramer probably
CC       differ in the extent of glycosylation; simultaneous glycosylation
CC       of all experimentally validated sites would probably create steric
CC       hindrance. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13563}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Morpholino knockdown of the protein impairs
CC       specification of the left-right axis during embryonic development
CC       and randomization of heart and gut looping, plus misexpression of
CC       left-side specific genes (PubMed:16216239, PubMed:16943304,
CC       PubMed:17360770, PubMed:26432887, PubMed:25660539). Morpholino
CC       knockdown of the protein causes body curvature, tail curling,
CC       hydrocephalus and kidney cysts (PubMed:15269167, PubMed:16216239,
CC       PubMed:16943304, PubMed:16551655, PubMed:17360770,
CC       PubMed:23376035, PubMed:26432887). Morpholino knockdown has no
CC       effect on number, length or motility of pronephric cilia, but the
CC       fluid flow through the pronephric ducts seems to be impaired due
CC       to physical obstruction of the ducts (PubMed:16943304). Likewise,
CC       morpholino knockdown of the protein has no effect on the motility
CC       of cilia in Kupffer's vesicle (PubMed:25660539). Morpholino
CC       knockdown of the protein leads to an increase of the volume of
CC       Kupffer's vesicle, without any change in the proliferation of the
CC       cells that line the vesicle (PubMed:26432887). Morpholino
CC       knockdown of the protein leads to impaired heart function,
CC       characterized by arrhytmia and frequently associated with
CC       pericardial and abdominal edema and atrioventricular block
CC       (PubMed:23376035). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15269167,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16216239, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16551655,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16943304, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17360770,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23376035, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26432887}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the polycystin family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Monovalent cation channel required for maintenance of
CC       rapid intracellular calcium release. May act as a potassium
CC       counter-ion channel that functions in synchronization with calcium
CC       release from intracellular stores. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q3TMP8}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotrimer; trimerization probably requires binding to
CC       phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:A5A6S6, ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9NA73}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Sarcoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:A5A6S6}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:A5A6S6}. Nucleus membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:A5A6S6}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TMEM38 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND INTERACTION WITH KCNB1 AND KCNB2.
RX   PubMed=9079713; DOI=10.1074/jbc.272.13.8774;
RA   Salinas M., de Weille J., Guillemare E., Lazdunski M., Hugnot J.-P.;
RT   "Modes of regulation of shab K+ channel activity by the Kv8.1
RT   subunit.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 272:8774-8780(1997).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Potassium channel subunit that does not form functional
CC       channels by itself. Modulates KCNB1 and KCNB2 channel activity by
CC       shifting the threshold for inactivation to more negative values
CC       and by slowing the rate of inactivation. Can down-regulate the
CC       channel activity of KCNB1, KCNB2, KCNC4 and KCND1, possibly by
CC       trapping them in intracellular membranes.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8670833, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9079713}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heteromultimer with KCNB1 and KCNB2. Interacts with KCNC4
CC       and KCND1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8670833,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9079713}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8670833,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9079713}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8670833, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9079713}. Note=Has
CC       to be associated with another potassium channel subunit to get
CC       inserted in the plasma membrane. Remains intracellular in the
CC       absence of KCNB2.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in brain.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12383276}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and is
CC       characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids at
CC       every third position. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. V (TC
CC       1.A.1.2) subfamily. Kv8.1/KCNV1 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   VARIANT [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] ILE-33.
RX   PubMed=16959974; DOI=10.1126/science.1133427;
RA   Sjoeblom T., Jones S., Wood L.D., Parsons D.W., Lin J., Barber T.D.,
RA   Mandelker D., Leary R.J., Ptak J., Silliman N., Szabo S.,
RA   Buckhaults P., Farrell C., Meeh P., Markowitz S.D., Willis J.,
RA   Dawson D., Willson J.K.V., Gazdar A.F., Hartigan J., Wu L., Liu C.,
RA   Parmigiani G., Park B.H., Bachman K.E., Papadopoulos N.,
RA   Vogelstein B., Kinzler K.W., Velculescu V.E.;
RT   "The consensus coding sequences of human breast and colorectal
RT   cancers.";
RL   Science 314:268-274(2006).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Outward rectifying potassium channel. Produces rapidly
CC       activating outward rectifier K(+) currents. Activated by high
CC       intracellular sodium and chloride levels. Channel activity is
CC       inhibited by ATP and by inhalation anesthetics, such as isoflurane
CC       (By similarity). Inhibited upon stimulation of G-protein coupled
CC       receptors, such as CHRM1 and GRIA1. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14684870, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16687497}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000250}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=4;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q6UVM3-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q6UVM3-2; Sequence=VSP_029855;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q6UVM3-3; Sequence=VSP_029854, VSP_029855, VSP_029856;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=Q6UVM3-4; Sequence=VSP_029852, VSP_029853, VSP_029855,
CC                                  VSP_029856, VSP_029857;
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated by protein kinase C. Phosphorylation of the C-
CC       terminal domain inhibits channel activity.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16687497}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. Calcium-
CC       activated (TC 1.A.1.3) subfamily. KCa4.2/KCNT2 sub-subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   INTERACTION WITH YWHAH, MUTAGENESIS OF SER-264, AND PHOSPHORYLATION AT
RP   SER-264.
RX   PubMed=18397886; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M800712200;
RA   Czirjak G., Vuity D., Enyedi P.;
RT   "Phosphorylation-dependent binding of 14-3-3 proteins controls TRESK
RT   regulation.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 283:15672-15680(2008).
RN   [8]
RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=18568022; DOI=10.1038/nn.2143;
RA   Bautista D.M., Sigal Y.M., Milstein A.D., Garrison J.L., Zorn J.A.,
RA   Tsuruda P.R., Nicoll R.A., Julius D.;
RT   "Pungent agents from Szechuan peppers excite sensory neurons by
RT   inhibiting two-pore potassium channels.";
RL   Nat. Neurosci. 11:772-779(2008).
RN   [9]
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, GLYCOSYLATION AT ASN-83, AND MUTAGENESIS OF
RP   ASN-83.
RX   PubMed=20006580; DOI=10.1016/j.bbrc.2009.12.056;
RA   Egenberger B., Polleichtner G., Wischmeyer E., Doring F.;
RT   "N-linked glycosylation determines cell surface expression of two-
RT   pore-domain K+ channel TRESK.";
RL   Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 391:1262-1267(2010).
RN   [10]
RP   TISSUE SPECIFICITY, AND DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE.
RX   PubMed=20871611; DOI=10.1038/nm.2216;
RA   Lafreniere R.G., Cader M.Z., Poulin J.F., Andres-Enguix I.,
RA   Simoneau M., Gupta N., Boisvert K., Lafreniere F., McLaughlan S.,
RA   Dube M.P., Marcinkiewicz M.M., Ramagopalan S., Ansorge O., Brais B.,
RA   Sequeiros J., Pereira-Monteiro J.M., Griffiths L.R., Tucker S.J.,
RA   Ebers G., Rouleau G.A.;
RT   "A dominant-negative mutation in the TRESK potassium channel is linked
RT   to familial migraine with aura.";
RL   Nat. Med. 16:1157-1160(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Outward rectifying potassium channel. Produces rapidly
CC       activating outward rectifier K(+) currents. May function as
CC       background potassium channel that sets the resting membrane
CC       potential. Channel activity is directly activated by calcium
CC       signal. Activated by the G(q)-protein coupled receptor pathway.
CC       The calcium signal robustly activates the channel via calcineurin,
CC       whereas the anchoring of 14-3-3/YWHAH interferes with the return
CC       of the current to the resting state after activation. Inhibited
CC       also by arachidonic acid and other naturally occurring unsaturated
CC       free fatty acids. Channel activity is also enhanced by volatile
CC       anesthetics, such as isoflurane. Appears to be the primary target
CC       of hydroxy-alpha-sanshool, an ingredient of Schezuan pepper. May
CC       be involved in the somatosensory function with special respect to
CC       pain sensation. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14981085,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16192517, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18568022}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with calcineurin. Interacts with YWHAH, in a
CC       phosphorylation-dependent manner. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16569637,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18397886}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20006580};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20006580}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in brain cortex, cerebellum, dorsal
CC       root ganglion, spinal cord and testis. High expression in
CC       trigeminal ganglion, also expressed in autonomic nervous system
CC       ganglia such as the stellate ganglion and paravertebral
CC       sympathetic ganglia. Expressed in all adult spinal cord and brain
CC       regions, with slightly higher expression in thalamus,
CC       hypothalamus, hippocampus and posterior corte (at protein level).
CC       In non-neuronal tissues, substantial expression found in lung and
CC       heart and weal expression in liver, testis, kidney, small
CC       intestine and spleen. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14981085,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16192517, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17962323,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20871611}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expression appears in trigeminal ganglion and
CC       dorsal root ganglia from E15.5 and increased through E18 to reach
CC       a peak in newborn mouse postnatal day 1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20871611}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation of Ser-264 is required for the binding of 14-
CC       3-3eta/YWHAH. Calcineurin-mediated dephosphorylation of Ser-276
CC       enhances channel activity. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14981085,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18397886}.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylated. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20006580}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Regulated by extracellular protons whereas human
CC       ortholog is not. His-132 is responsible for proton-dependent
CC       specific activity.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the two pore domain potassium channel (TC
CC       1.A.1.8) family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- WEB RESOURCE: Name=Protein Spotlight; Note=Throb - Issue 124 of
CC       December 2010;
CC       URL="https://web.expasy.org/spotlight/back_issues/124";

CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA] OF 290-855.
RC   STRAIN=cv. Nipponbare;
RX   PubMed=12869764; DOI=10.1126/science.1081288;

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Probable inward-rectifying potassium channel. Assuming
CC       opened or closed conformations in response to the voltage
CC       difference across the membrane, the channel is activated by
CC       hyperpolarization (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The potassium channel is probably a homo- or
CC       heterotetrameric complex of pore-forming subunits. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and is
CC       characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids. The
CC       pore-forming region H5 is enclosed by the transmembrane segments
CC       S5 and S6 in the Shaker-type (1P/6TM) and contains the GYGD
CC       signature motif which seems to be involved in potassium
CC       selectivity (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The KHA domain (rich in hydrophobic and acidic residues)
CC       present in the C-terminal part is likely to be important for
CC       tetramerization. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. Plant (TC
CC       1.A.1.4) subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAV59417.1; Type=Erroneous gene model prediction; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=BAF17528.1; Type=Erroneous gene model prediction; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (3.30 ANGSTROMS) OF 44-359 IN COMPLEXES WITH
RP   PROPOFOL AND DESFLURANE ANESTHETICS, AND MUTAGENESIS OF ILE-244;
RP   VAL-284 AND THR-297.
RC   STRAIN=PCC 7421;
RX   PubMed=21248852; DOI=10.1038/nature09647;
RA   Nury H., Van Renterghem C., Weng Y., Tran A., Baaden M., Dusfresne V.,
RA   Changeux J.P., Sonner J.M., Delarue M., Corringer P.J.;
RT   "X-ray structures of general anaesthetics bound to a pentameric
RT   ligand-gated ion channel.";
RL   Nature 469:428-431(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Cationic channel with similar permeabilities for Na(+)
CC       and K(+), that is activated by an increase of the proton
CC       concentration on the extracellular side. Displays no permeability
CC       for chloride ions. Shows slow kinetics of activation, no
CC       desensitization and a single channel conductance of 8 pS. Might
CC       contribute to adaptation to external pH change.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17167423}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Tetraethylammonium (TEA) and tetrabutylammonium
CC       (TBA) inhibit the proton-activated currents in a dose- and
CC       voltage-dependent manner in vitro, whereas the blocker of acid
CC       sensing ion channels, amiloride, has no effect. Channel current of
CC       GLIC can be inhibited by inhaled and intravenous general
CC       anesthetics at and below concentrations used clinically. Ion
CC       conduction is also inhibited by lidocaine and by divalent
CC       transition metal ions such as cadmium ions.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17167423, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19933531,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21037567}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homopentamer. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17167423,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18987630, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18987633}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=26; IntAct=EBI-8423601, EBI-8423601;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Consists of an N-terminal ligand-binding domain that
CC       encloses a wide aqueous vestibule and a transmembrane domain that
CC       forms a narrow channel.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The homologous nature of GLIC to eukaryotic
CC       nicotinic acetylcholine receptors and other eukaryotic pentameric
CC       ligand-gated ion channels, and its sensitivity to general
CC       anesthetics, define GLIC as a structural and functional model of
CC       signal transduction in the nervous system, also relevant for
CC       exploring the molecular basis of anesthetic action.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC       signature motif which seems to be involved in potassium

RA   Lafreniere R.G., Cader M.Z., Poulin J.F., Andres-Enguix I.,

RT   to familial migraine with aura.";

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Outward rectifying potassium channel. Produces rapidly
CC       activating outward rectifier K(+) currents. May function as
CC       background potassium channel that sets the resting membrane
CC       potential. Channel activity is directly activated by calcium
CC       signal. Activated by the G(q)-protein coupled receptor pathway.
CC       The calcium signal robustly activates the channel via calcineurin,
CC       whereas the anchoring of 14-3-3/YWHAH interferes with the return
CC       of the current to the resting state after activation. Inhibited
CC       also by arachidonic acid and other naturally occurring unsaturated
CC       free fatty acids. Channel activity is also enhanced by volatile
CC       anesthetics, such as isoflurane. Appears to be the primary target
CC       of hydroxy-alpha-sanshool, an ingredient of Schezuan pepper. May
CC       be involved in the somatosensory function with special respect to
CC       pain sensation (By similarity). {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12754259, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15562060}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with calcineurin. Interacts with YWHAH, in a
CC       phosphorylation-dependent manner. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20006580};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20006580}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed specifically in dorsal root ganglion
CC       and trigeminal ganglion neurons. Detected at low levels in spinal
CC       cord. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12754259, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15562060,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20871611}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation of Ser-252 is required for the binding of 14-
CC       3-3eta/YWHAH. Calcineurin-mediated dephosphorylation of Ser-264
CC       enhances channel activity (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylated. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20006580}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Migraine with or without aura 13 (MGR13) [MIM:613656]: A
CC       form of migraine transmitted in an autosomal dominant pattern.
CC       Migraine is a disabling symptom complex of periodic headaches,
CC       usually temporal and unilateral. Headaches are often accompanied
CC       by irritability, nausea, vomiting and photophobia, preceded by
CC       constriction of the cranial arteries. The two major subtypes are
CC       common migraine (migraine without aura) and classic migraine
CC       (migraine with aura). Classic migraine is characterized by
CC       recurrent attacks of reversible neurological symptoms (aura) that
CC       precede or accompany the headache. Aura may include a combination
CC       of sensory disturbances, such as blurred vision, hallucinations,
CC       vertigo, numbness and difficulty in concentrating and speaking.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20871611}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC       Susceptibility to migraine has been shown to be conferred by a
CC       frameshift mutation that segregates with the disorder in a large
CC       multigenerational family. Migraine was associated with sensitivity
CC       to lights, sounds, and smells, as well as nausea and occasional
CC       vomiting. Triggers included fatigue, alcohol and bright lights.
CC       Mutations in KCNK18 are a rare cause of migraine.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: In contrast to its mouse ortholog, it is not
CC       regulated by extracellular protons.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the two pore domain potassium channel (TC
CC       1.A.1.8) family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC       December 2010;
CC       URL="https://web.expasy.org/spotlight/back_issues/124";

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Monovalent cation channel required for maintenance of
CC       rapid intracellular calcium release. May act as a potassium
CC       counter-ion channel that functions in synchronization with calcium
CC       release from intracellular stores. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9DAV9}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotrimer; trimerization probably requires binding to
CC       phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:A5A6S6, ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9NA73}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9DAV9}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9DAV9}.

ID   KCNG4_MOUSE             Reviewed;         506 AA.
AC   Q80XM3;
DT   26-FEB-2008, integrated into UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot.
DT   01-JUN-2003, sequence version 1.
DT   22-NOV-2017, entry version 118.
DE   RecName: Full=Potassium voltage-gated channel subfamily G member 4;
DE   AltName: Full=Voltage-gated potassium channel subunit Kv6.4;
GN   Name=Kcng4;
OS   Mus musculus (Mouse).
OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Chordata; Craniata; Vertebrata; Euteleostomi;
OC   Mammalia; Eutheria; Euarchontoglires; Glires; Rodentia; Myomorpha;
OC   Muroidea; Muridae; Murinae; Mus; Mus.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=10090;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA].
RA   Preisig-Mueller R., Derst C., Schnitzler M.M., Daut J.;
RT   "Cloning and characterization of two novel gamma Kv subunits.";
RL   Submitted (NOV-2001) to the EMBL/GenBank/DDBJ databases.
RN   [2]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA].
RC   TISSUE=Eye;
RX   PubMed=15489334; DOI=10.1101/gr.2596504;
RG   The MGC Project Team;
RT   "The status, quality, and expansion of the NIH full-length cDNA
RT   project: the Mammalian Gene Collection (MGC).";
RL   Genome Res. 14:2121-2127(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Potassium channel subunit that does not form functional
CC       channels by itself. Can form functional heterotetrameric channels
CC       with KCNB1; modulates the delayed rectifier voltage-gated
CC       potassium channel activation and deactivation rates of KCNB1.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8TDN1}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer with KCNB1.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8TDN1}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8TDN1}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8TDN1}. Note=Has to be associated with
CC       KCNB1 or possibly another partner to get inserted in the plasma
CC       membrane. Colocalizes with KCNB1 at the plasma membrane. Remains
CC       intracellular in the absence of KCNB1.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8TDN1}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The transmembrane segment S4 functions as voltage-sensor
CC       and is characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids
CC       at every third position. Channel opening and closing is effected
CC       by a conformation change that affects the position and orientation
CC       of the voltage-sensor paddle formed by S3 and S4 within the
CC       membrane. A transmembrane electric field that is positive inside
CC       would push the positively charged S4 segment outwards, thereby
CC       opening the pore, while a field that is negative inside would pull
CC       the S4 segment inwards and close the pore. Changes in the position
CC       and orientation of S4 are then transmitted to the activation gate
CC       formed by the inner helix bundle via the S4-S5 linker region.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P63142}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. G (TC
CC       1.A.1.2) subfamily. Kv6.4/KCNG4 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Lacombe B., Pilot G., Michard E., Gaymard F., Sentenac H.,

RN   [6]
RP   GENE FAMILY, AND NOMENCLATURE.
RX   PubMed=11500563; DOI=10.1104/pp.126.4.1646;
RA   Maeser P., Thomine S., Schroeder J.I., Ward J.M., Hirschi K., Sze H.,
RA   Talke I.N., Amtmann A., Maathuis F.J.M., Sanders D., Harper J.F.,
RA   Tchieu J., Gribskov M., Persans M.W., Salt D.E., Kim S.A.,
RA   Guerinot M.L.;
RT   "Phylogenetic relationships within cation transporter families of
RT   Arabidopsis.";
RL   Plant Physiol. 126:1646-1667(2001).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Highly selective inward-rectifying potassium channel
CC       that could mediate potassium uptake in the pollen membrane. Plays
CC       an important role in pollen tube development. Assuming opened or
CC       closed conformations in response to the voltage difference across
CC       the membrane, the channel is activated by hyperpolarization. May
CC       interact with the cytoskeleton or with regulatory proteins.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11825875}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The potassium channel is probably composed of a homo- or
CC       heterotetrameric complex of pore-forming subunits. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Predominantly expressed in flowers; especially
CC       in pollen. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10852932,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11825875}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and is
CC       characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids. The
CC       pore-forming region H5 is enclosed by the transmembrane segments
CC       S5 and S6 in the Shaker-type (1P/6TM) and contains the GYGD
CC       signature motif which seems to be involved in potassium
CC       selectivity.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The KHA domain (rich in hydrophobic and acidic residues)
CC       present in the C-terminal part is likely to be important for
CC       tetramerization.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. Plant (TC
CC       1.A.1.4) subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: Was originally erroneously termed AKT5.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:10852932}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

RA   Kawahara Y., de la Bastide M., Hamilton J.P., Kanamori H.,

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Probable inward-rectifying potassium channel. Assuming
CC       opened or closed conformations in response to the voltage
CC       difference across the membrane, the channel is activated by
CC       hyperpolarization (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and is
CC       characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids. The
CC       pore-forming region H5 is enclosed by the transmembrane segments
CC       S5 and S6 in the Shaker-type (1P/6TM) and contains the GYGD
CC       signature motif which seems to be involved in potassium
CC       selectivity (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The KHA domain (rich in hydrophobic and acidic residues)
CC       present in the C-terminal part is likely to be important for
CC       tetramerization. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. Plant (TC
CC       1.A.1.4) subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=BAH93802.1; Type=Erroneous gene model prediction; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Mediates the voltage-dependent potassium ion
CC       permeability of excitable membranes. Has an important role in
CC       repolarization and in regulating the pattern of action potential
CC       firing. Isoform a expresses currents in a more depolarized voltage
CC       range than isoform d. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16899454,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21059759}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P08510};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P08510}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:

RN   [16]
RP   FUNCTION, SUBUNIT, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND GLYCOSYLATION.
RC   STRAIN=cv. Columbia;
RX   PubMed=21697507; DOI=10.1104/pp.111.177816;
RA   Maitrejean M., Wudick M.M., Voelker C., Prinsi B., Mueller-Roeber B.,
RA   Czempinski K., Pedrazzini E., Vitale A.;
RT   "Assembly and sorting of the tonoplast potassium channel AtTPK1 and
RT   its turnover by internalization into the vacuole.";
RL   Plant Physiol. 156:1783-1796(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-independent, large conductance and potassium-
CC       selective tonoplast ion channel. Regulated by cytoplasmic calcium
CC       and pH. Does not mediate slow-vacuolar (SV) ionic currents, but
CC       essential to establish VK currents. Has some permeability for
CC       Rb(+) and NH(4)(+), but none for Na(+), Cs(+) or Li(+). Involved
CC       in intracellular K(+) redistribution and/or K(+) retranslocation
CC       between different tissues. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16113216,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17563365, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17764516,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21697507}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Could be activated by protein kinase C (By
CC       similarity). Strongly induced by calcium. Blocked by barium,
CC       tetraethylammonium (TEA), quinine and quinidine. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16113216, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17563365}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. Interacts with GRF1 and GRF6, but only GRF6
CC       modulates the channel activity. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16984403,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17764516, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21697507}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Vacuole membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12148538, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19825594,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21697507}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12148538, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19825594,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21697507}. Note=Tonoplast.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in mesophyll cells, guard cells and
CC       vascular tissues of the leaves. Expressed in the hilum, where the
CC       funiculus is attached during fruit maturation and in the embryo.
CC       Also expressed at a lower level in seedlings, root tips and
CC       elongation zones, and flowers. Could be detected in mitotically
CC       active tissues. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12148538,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16984403}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Each of the two pore-forming region (also called P-domain
CC       or P-loop) is enclosed by two transmembrane segments (2P/4TM) and
CC       contains the GYGD signature motif which seems to be involved in
CC       potassium selectivity. The C-terminus (328-363) is required for
CC       vacuolar targeting.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation at Ser-42 increases and stabilizes the
CC       interaction with 14-3-3 proteins. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17764516}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Reduced growth in both high and low K(+)
CC       conditions. Slower germination and increased sensitivity to
CC       abscisic acid. Reduction of the total tonoplast current density.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17563365}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: 14-3-3 protein binding is not involved in
CC       endoplasmic reticulum export and tonoplast targeting.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the two pore domain potassium channel (TC
CC       1.A.1.7) family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: Was initially described as an outward slow-vacuolar (SV)
CC       ion channel (PubMed:9184204 and PubMed:11821043). {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND MUTAGENESIS OF ASP-295.
RX   PubMed=21224427; DOI=10.1105/tpc.110.081463;
RA   Isayenkov S., Isner J.C., Maathuis F.J.;
RT   "Rice two-pore K+ channels are expressed in different types of
RT   vacuoles.";
RL   Plant Cell 23:756-768(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Highly selective inward-rectifying potassium channel
CC       that is specifically located in the tonoplast of protein storage
CC       vacuoles. Functions independently of the voltage difference across
CC       the membrane. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21224427}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Vacuole membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21224427}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21224427}. Note=Tonoplast of protein storage
CC       vacuoles.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Each of the two pore-forming region (also called P-domain
CC       or P-loop) is enclosed by two transmembrane segments (2P/4TM) and
CC       contains the GYGD signature motif which seems to be involved in
CC       potassium selectivity.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the two pore domain potassium channel (TC
CC       1.A.1.7) family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [7]
RP   FUNCTION, SUBUNIT, AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=19074135; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M808786200;
RA   Mederos y Schnitzler M., Rinne S., Skrobek L., Renigunta V.,
RA   Schlichthorl G., Derst C., Gudermann T., Daut J., Preisig-Muller R.;
RT   "Mutation of histidine 105 in the T1 domain of the potassium channel
RT   Kv2.1 disrupts heteromerization with Kv6.3 and Kv6.4.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 284:4695-4704(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Potassium channel subunit that does not form functional
CC       channels by itself (PubMed:11852086). Can form functional
CC       heterotetrameric channels with KCNB1; this promotes a reduction in
CC       the rate of activation and inactivation of the delayed rectifier
CC       voltage-gated potassium channel KCNB1 (PubMed:11852086,
CC       PubMed:19074135). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11852086,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19074135}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer with KCNB1 (PubMed:11852086,
CC       PubMed:12060745, PubMed:19074135). Does not form homomultimers
CC       (PubMed:12060745). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11852086,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12060745, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19074135}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11852086,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12060745, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19074135}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}. Cytoplasm
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12060745}. Note=Has to be associated with
CC       KCNB1 or possibly another partner to get inserted in the plasma
CC       membrane (PubMed:12060745). Colocalizes with KCNB1 at the plasma
CC       membrane (PubMed:12060745, PubMed:19074135). Remains intracellular
CC       in the absence of KCNB1 (PubMed:12060745).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12060745, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19074135}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=Kv10.1b;
CC         IsoId=Q8TAE7-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=Kv10.1a;
CC         IsoId=Q8TAE7-2; Sequence=VSP_001026;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in the brain, liver, testis, small
CC       intestine, colon, thymus and adrenal gland (PubMed:11852086,
CC       PubMed:12060745). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11852086,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12060745}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The transmembrane segment S4 functions as voltage-sensor
CC       and is characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids
CC       at every third position. Channel opening and closing is effected
CC       by a conformation change that affects the position and orientation
CC       of the voltage-sensor paddle formed by S3 and S4 within the
CC       membrane. A transmembrane electric field that is positive inside
CC       would push the positively charged S4 segment outwards, thereby
CC       opening the pore, while a field that is negative inside would pull
CC       the S4 segment inwards and close the pore. Changes in the position
CC       and orientation of S4 are then transmitted to the activation gate
CC       formed by the inner helix bundle via the S4-S5 linker region.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P63142}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel family. G (TC
CC       1.A.1.2) subfamily. Kv6.3/KCNG3 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   INTERACTION WITH KCNQ1.
RX   PubMed=20533308; DOI=10.1002/jcp.22265;
RA   Roura-Ferrer M., Sole L., Oliveras A., Dahan R., Bielanska J.,
RA   Villarroel A., Comes N., Felipe A.;

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Ancillary protein that assembles as a beta subunit with
CC       a voltage-gated potassium channel complex of pore-forming alpha
CC       subunits. Modulates the gating kinetics and enhances stability of
CC       the channel complex. May associate with KCNQ1/KVLTQ1 and inhibit
CC       potassium current.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with KCNQ1; impairs KCNQ1 localization in lipid
CC       rafts and inhibits voltage-gated potassium channel activity.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12096056, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19687231,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20533308}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000305}; Single-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Predominantly expressed in embryo and adult
CC       uterus. Low expression found in kidney, small intestine, lung and
CC       heart. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12096056}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel KCNE family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAH14429.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally extended.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=AAL49979.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally extended.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
